Battlefield: Bad Company 2  Field Rating Review   Graphics 9 A beautifully rendered world, extremely satisfying levels of destruction, grand animations, and an easy to understand interface. Battlefield: Bad Company 2 has it all.   Gameplay 9 At times, it feels like there are some frustrating balance issues. But those are few and far between. Bad Company 2 is a fantastic game to pick up and go to town with. You'll find glee in causing buildings to crumble around you, planting that charge of C4 on a tank and blowing it up, nailing that perfect headshot from across the map. However, where Bad Company 2 really shines is when you log on with some friends and get coordinated. Communicate and work together to outgun, outflank, and outdo the enemy team.   Story 4 I'll be honest with you. If you are playing Battlefield games for the story, you're going to be really, really disappointed. While there is a storymode here, it honestly isn't worth much of your time except as a glorified tutorial. The characters do give a few good laughs though.   Multiplayer 10 As mentioned earlier, Bad Company 2 really shines when you play with friends, but even alone you're going to have a blast with this one. Hours and hours of fun and destruction await you, with several different modes of multiplayer available to choose from. Be warned though, if you join up this late in the game you're going to face some very, very good long-time players.   Replayability 9 You're going to keep coming back to this one. The peak of the Battlefield series so far, it never gets old racing out of a building as it crumbles around you, covering your team on a withdrawal from an overrun area, or being at the front of a charge to capture a point. Don't miss out on one of the most enjoyable Battlefield experiences yet. The only struggle here is that most your friends will probably have moved on to the new battlefields.   Overall 9.2/10 Though not as popular as it once was (due to the new battlefields) Bad Company 2 still stands at the top of the Battlefield mountain. The Frostbite engine really shines in this iteration. Multiplayer is fast-paced, brutal, and spectacularly fun. Don't like those trees? Mow them down with your LMG. Don't like that building? Blow it up. Your team being overrun? Call in an artillery strike and give them some relief. All in all, an absolute must have for any Battlefield fan. If you liked this review, feel free to check out my curator page:The TipsterYou are also welcome to join our group and play/discuss games together, here:  The Tipster

												Battlefield : Bad Company 2 might be the only current-gen/next-gen Battlefield game to not be stained by EA greediness. Just wait before the franchise turns into a free-to-play game with microtransactions and before it invades the Android platform.The community is still active even nowadays. And yet the game is still the most overlooked Battlefield of the franchise.PROS :+Very arcadish gameplay that features unrealistic shooting mechanics and lots of destroyable buildings+Doesn't require Origin to play+Ingame servers browser and matchmaking system (no web browsing à la BF3 BF4)+No premium account, season pass or whatever you call it+No multiplayer map packs à la Call of Duty, feels like a complete game by itself+No unlock purchase+A fun singleplayer campaign (not excellent but nonetheless good)+One amazing DLC that feels like a Total Conversion or a reskin of Battlefield in the Vietnam War eraCONS :-No 64 players maps-No option to change the narrow field of view (default 65) except in the .ini document-Unlike Battlefield 2, Bad Company 2 features no mod-Bad Company 2 Vietnam servers are almost empty (if you're lucky you may find two active servers)Old doesn't mean obsolete!Forget about Battlefield 3 and 4 and be part of the Bad Company!P.S.: Don't mistake me. BF3 and BF4 are quite fun. I just dislike the marketing philosophy behind it. I haven't played BF Hardline yet so I can't say anything about it.Rating :9.0

BEST BUY EVER! AND STILL POPULATED! (20-100 full servers at all times! NA - Eu/Russia - Oceania)Bought it 3 times:- Disk: 20€- Steam: 2.5€- Origin: 2€Time in-game > 3000 hours:- Disk: +- 2500h- Steam: 350h- Origin: 350h The SPNot that important to me, but even so I finished it three times (2x normal and 1x hard). The gameplay was OK, but like I said I'm not really a sp kinda guy.Pros (Multiplayer)+++ The gameplay is just... really this game has a soul people!! The feeling guys, it's amazing :D++ Brilliant map design. (flanking possibilities etc)++ Huge terrain variation. (jungle/ snow and desert)++ Almost everything is destructable. ++ Class system is great and rewards teamplay!++ Separate level and class unlocks.++ Vehicles are fun and rewarding when mastered but still balanced.++ Does not force battlelog or origin on its users.++ It can be soooooo much fun :D++ It goes on sale for 2.5€.... seriously?+ You can change FOV in settings file.+ Decent amount of graphical options.+ Imo the graphics (maxed out) beat a lot of 2014 titles to it.+ Requirements are pretty low.+ Never had issues that couldn't be easily fixed (like crashes etc).+ I found the amount of attachements a bit overwhelming in bf3, not the case here.Cons (Multiplayer)-- The hitreg isn't always as it should be.-- The community (players). (people who claim there are cheaters in every round have no idea what they're talking about)Conclusion:This game is amazing. The graphics and gameplay create such a unique atmosphere, I can keep playing it for hours and hours and just keep coming back for more. The only reasons why I don't play it 24/7 are the hitreg and the community. (Since you asked)1. Boot the game.2. Click 'Login'. (right - center)3. Enter Email and PW of your EA account.-->Some people can't login when the boxes for remember PW/ Auto login are checked.4. Select or create a soldier and click 'Login'5. Click 'Multiplayer' (top center) and select 'Server browser' (2nd option).6. Look at the 'Filter Options' (right center).7. Select 'Register code' or something simular (mid center). 11. Paste the key from steam here and follow the procedure.12. Go back to steam and boot bc2 from the library.13. Click 'Login' (right center).14. Enter the email and password from you ORIGIN ACCOUNT.HAVE FUN!TheHornyHippo/SpreadDemCheeks/MachoMoose/AnalAnaconda

Server situation (GBR) 
A Screenshot of Battlefield: Bad Company 2
By: Ol' Dirty Badger




Taken 27/06/2016 (Steam summer sale 2016)Now that's out of the way, you can buy this game. Cause it's awesome.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------For those looking for an actual review..MULTIPLAYER: For me, and quite a few people it seems, this is the best battlefield released to date. It's the most fun and most well made addition to the series and I think it's down to the simplicity of it's loadout system, as well as the great team and game play, and of course the destruction that every one loves. When you jump onto Battlefield 4, I feel its too complex for its own good. way to many class options and quite a few flawed items that became over powered (Especially a lot of the DLC weapons and gadgets that they released) BC2 gives you a good selection of guns and perk options without going overboard. There are one or two things I would maybe change (Magnum rounds and the shotty slug rounds) but everyhting else works well.The maps are really awesome, some better on different modes than others, and some you can only play on certain modes, a bit weird really. But they're all pretty awesome. rush and conquest are the main game modes available, along with squad deathmatch and squad rush, but just stick with rush and conquest. The general gameplay is standard battlefield fare, just awesome. Stuff's blowing up all over the place, soldiers are shouting their heads off about snipers blowing their mates head off, bullets are wizzing past and it combines to make probably, in my opinion, the most cinematic war experience ever made for a multiplayer game. Some people will be craving jet gameplay and the more varied vehicles that BF3 and BF4 have, but the ones available are all you need. Unfortunatley though there are no jets, for those that didn't know.And the audio... it's the best ( And make sure you go into the audio settings and turn on war tapes)SINGLEPLAYER:Decent for one playthrough I guess, played it on the 360 back in the day once and never really went back to it apart for achievements, but it's not the worst campaign ever. Not big, open free roam areas like BC1 had in the singleplayer which is a shame, but the characters and action are interesting enough to keep you interested.So overall:Multiplayer 9.5/10Singleplayer 7/10Audio 11/10The audio's so good...Buy it while it's cheap people.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												The best multiplatform shooter. Whereas CoD has you sprinting off by yourself, drop-shotting, and camping with some twitch-shoot mechanics. Battlefield encompasses the features that made people play First Person Shooters to begin with -- the feeling of being in a battle. Several factors contribute to this. The graphics are not the best out there, but they're very solid, much better than the first Bad Company which suffered from a grainy effect and low view-distance. Atmospheric effects (sand, debris, smoke) are done brilliantly and are wonderfully varying. One second you can looking down your scope in the desert and see everything laid out clearly. The next, looking in the same exact spot, your vision can be distorted by a rogue burst of wind and sand. The sound quality is even better, arguably unrivaled in gaming. Distant sound occurs a second or two after the event, giving the impression of a larger battle. The campaign is about standard for modern FPSs, which is why I didn't go into detail, but the multiplayer has no equals -- Bad Company really is in its own category.

The last Battlefield with full destructionBattlefield: Bad Company 2 holds a special place in my heart. I love Vietnam War movies, games and music and this game just happens to have a Vietnam War expansion pack. It really nails the expansion too. The weapons, the scenarios, maps, music, vehicles...it's all so very well done. The expansion pack is multiplayer only and it's epic!Singleplayer campaign is pretty "CoD-like" linear most of the time.  There are some sandboxy areas but for the most of time it's your simple corridor shooter.Make no mistake tho, the campaign is very enjoyable. It's not a serious shooter. It has a bunch of good humour in it, fantastic characters, pwetty graphiczzz and a vast variety of locations: deserts, snowy areas and jungles - I love me some jungles and xmas areas, man.It's about 8 hours long. Nothing special...no replay value, really. But it is fun for what it is and i guess you could go and replay it just for the heck of it.The Multiplayer is why people play Battlefield. Battlefield used to be a multiplayer only game. The first time it had a singleplayer campaign was back in 2007 in Battlefield: Bad Company. That game is a console exclusive tho.So this is actually the first Battlefield game that features a singleplayer campaign on the PC Entertainment System.Multiplayer is just awesome. Everything can be destroyed. Now don't get me wrong, i do love me some BF3 and BF4. I don't hate on them like other "hardcore" Battlefield fans. The hate is childish and quite ignorant to be honest. Nothing wrong with Battlefield 4 (it had a bad launch but it's OK now) and Battlefield 3...nothing bad to say about that game...but back to the point: Bad Company 2 lets you blow up everything! In later BFs you can only blow up certain walls or buildings. In here there's no boundaries!Blow up trees, blow up houses, blow boats, blow up water...explosion! EXPLOSION! EXPLOSIOONN!! EXPLOSIOOOOOOONNNNNN!!!! PROMOTEEEEEEED!!!!!Khm, as i was saying, the multiplayer is quite fun. Especially epic with friends but you can do very well when playing alone too.Just like in singleplayer, there are quite a good variety of locations: jungles, forests, xmas, deserts, plain fields. + The Vietnam expansion which adds A LOT to the epicness. Feels like a totally new game.32v32 player multiplayer, 5 people squads - Lots of shooting going on, lots of explosions, lots of raging.4 different classes: revive/heal your teammates, give them ammo or bring down tanks by yourself - Teamwork is rewarded. Don't ignore your teams needs...or ignore them. I'm not your daddy and you're a free kiddo. Do whatever you want in this virtual world of ours.Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is worth every single penny. If you're looking for a massive multiplayer game where you could destroy everything you see...man, look no further!

content:
Posted: February 5
												Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is a team-based MMOFPS capture-the-checkpoint game based on massive maps. As you may have known, its sucessors are having a huge sucess. Battlefield easily became one of the iconic PC FPS game beside CoD and CSGO. BF: BC2 seriously blew my mind on both gameplay and graphics quality. As a 2010 game, I did not expect much from it. I got this on a massive sale and grabbed a few copies to send to my friends. I tested 3-4 levels of the SP and had some MP matches with my groupmates. Here are the pros and cons I pulled from it:Pros:+ Amazing optimization and graphics quality. Similar to its successors, this game is highly optimized. This means you can run BF games on bottleneck PCs with 60 fps. Graphics quality that is offered with this level of minimum specs are also amazing.+ Classic Battlefield unforgiving & challenging shooting recoil. You can't point-and-shoot with laser-pinpoint accuracy like *cough*Call of Duty*cough*+ Again, similar to its successors, the gameplay keeps a great balance between realism and entertaining arcade system. You can't run around no-scoping people with sniper rifles, but you sure won't get killed with 1 body shot like in Arma 3.+ Servers & community are still active, most of them has x15 XP so you can rank up very quickly to unlock the weapons. A lot of people are still playing this game.+ Bullet drop already exists, not as harsh as BF4 but it poses a challenge to snipers.+ Tons of weapon choices+ Steep, but enjoyable learning curve. Not as harsh as CSGO and not as lean as Call of Duty.+ Definitely fun to play with your friends. Get them into a squad, turn your voice chat on, and go have a blast.+ Perfect game to test the Battlefield experience. If you're afraid your money will go to waste on BF3/BF4/BFH/BF1, try this game first. Although the elements are very different, general gameplay is similar.+ Haven't met any imperious server admins that enforces weird rules like in later BF games.+ Classic BF destructible environmentCons:- Still K/D focused. Players are not really motivated to work with their team and solely focus on their own K/D. Players rarely bothers to capture a point and chose to sit on top of a hill with a sniper rifle instead. - Too many veteran players. Some people simply don't get bored with old games and they stay here for years. Arrogant veterans are squashing new players with helicopters/snipers.- Base♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥is hardly controlled. Veteran players can easily find a sweet spot to camp the freshly spawned players. You basically will not have any chance to fight back if someone does this. Some servers kill these people but they often find loopholes to base♥♥♥♥♥♥e.g. destroying freshly spawned vehicle- I personally don't fancy the shooting. It's a bit wonky and awkward compared to other FPS games. I'm a 16-years FPS veteran that usually learns the pattern of new FPS games very quickly and can gain a headstart. In this particular game, it is very difficult for me to adapt.- Adding friends seem to be very difficult in this game. It took me days and multiple tries to have my friend request sent to my groupmatesIn conclusion, BF: BC2 is definitely worth it.  I wouldn't say that this game is better than its successors since I'm very meticulos with graphical quality and I despise downgrading games that I play. I would choose to play BF4/BF1 all day over BF: BC2.  However, this is an especially great game for people with bare-necessities PC specs or considering to purchase EA Origin's BF1/BF4/BFH. I hope my review can be helpful in your decision.Thank you for reading!

PROS:+ cool & cheesy campaign+ nice soundtrack (made fantastic in the Vietnam expansion)+ vehicles are fun+ collectable weapons+ destructible environment+ funny dialogue+ great multiplayer+ still plenty of people in multiplayerCONS:- a bit short campaign- some weapons become useless- enemies always focus fire on you- sand/snow storms blind a bit too much?- EA account needed for multiplayerComment:The logo looks like BF3 which might get people confused. Because, unlike the main BF franchize known for seriousness, Bad Company is lovably goofy. Best way to describe the mood is "less serious CoD:MW" mixed with "a parody of an american action movie". Unlike the previous Bad Company game we can enjoy this one on the PC too, although it is missing one DLC on the PC (Onslaught expansion which is a multiplayer co-op game mode). We are greeted with a WW2 intro/tutorial mission but the main game is played within a USA vs Russia conflict set in the present. The campaign is cool, fun and it keeps this tone for the most of the game. You will probably find your two or three favourite weapons and play those. First playthrough is good but once you unlock all the weapons you get to choose how you want to play. Which in my case was running around destroying everything with the rocket launcher. Unlike the collectable weapons that unlock for later use (or to have them already when replaying the campaign) the m-com stations serve little purpose than to distract. There could have been perhaps less (or more?) enemies if you find and disable one of these stations ... or at least extra dialogue. Your team buddies can actually kill enemies although the focus stays on you so you don't get bored letting your (immortal) mates do all the work. You all make a stereotypical gang - the smart one with glasses, the tough one, the sarge and the basic/vanilla one which you play. The slightly dated graphics still hold their charm though there are some graphical hick-ups - like tank threads that do not move. And I know it's kind of stupid to say but sand and snow storms hinder your vision a lot more than they maybe should. Because of this you either have to know where your enemy is or you have to be lucky. These storms are also annoying when driving around in vehicles and avoiding cliffs. The multiplayer is a blast and is still one of the best FPS multiplayers (even more if you have the Vietnam expansion). The playerbase is still good so check it out. There are more players in the default multiplayer than the Vietnam expansion but try that out too, it is awesome. Overall this is not a perfect game, it has flaws, but these can be overlooked due to the sheer fun factor of it. Get the bundle!

You can choose between 4 classes which each specialise in something. There are usually a couple of servers with players, but most are empty. Sometimes you will get killed by an Apache while at spawn. Vision on lowest graphics at least is kinda bad and the size of the maps doesn't help at all. You can get killed by a hundred different things and you might not even understand what was going on.I'd recommend this game if its on sale.

Posted: November 16, 2014
												tl;dr: HIGHLY reccommend getting this game. Ignoring the mediocre campaign and occasional server frustrations, this is probably the best fps I've ever played.Even though I moved to a rural area and can no longer play it's muliplayer, I still regard this game very highly. If you have the money to spare, I can almost guarantee that you won't be disappointed. I have no idea what the servers are like these days, but back when I played it, the minor hiccup with the punkbuster service was overshadowed by the dedicated server support. Even the campaign is a fun playthrough for the first couple of times.What it does right: Where to begin. This is what an fps should feel like. The guns are satisfying to shoot, and kills are an amazing gratification in multiplayer. Everything is smooth and works well, with nothing seeming out of balance if you know which situation to use it in. The massive maps and inclusion of vehicles pretty much necessitates that every match of conquest or mcom needs to be a team effort, and makes this easy with the squad system. The endless unlocks and medals in the multiplayer ensure you always have a goal to work for, and make sure you never stick with one playstyle long enough to get bored with it.The multiplayer was the most fun I think I've ever had with an fps. The maps are always just the right size to ensure that you can't miss out on the action if there's a full lineup on the server, and with all the variables on each map there's never a dull moment, and every match is a different experience.Moving away from multiplayer, the singleplayer campaign was surprisingly enjoyable as well. The typical 'russians invading the world' plot bores me to death, but with the likeable characters at the forefront, and throwing out the traditional sense of taking everything way too seriously, this campaign was much more enjoyable than others of the same type. Most COD or even later battlefield games just take themselves too seriously, and the constant quips from the characters and such make it so that's never a problem.What it does wrong: EA has never been very good at dealing with customers, and the punkbuster service is no exception. Not only is it an extra account that has to be logged into every time you want to play multiplayer, but sometimes it doesn't even work for multiple attemtps. It can get really frustrating when I just want to play the game. I've heard it was to curb piracy and hacking in the game, but all it really does is inconvenience the actual paying customers. It wasn't a good design choice, especially if EA stops checking up on the servers entirely. I would hate to see an entire game broken because of the lack of consideration by the publisher, but with who we're talking about, it wouldn't be surprising.Another complaint might be the campaign. I know I said it was good, but especially on later playthroughs it can get really repetitive at times. The varied locations are nice, but there's really no reason to play through the campaign to find intel or something once you've beaten it once. This game really shines in the multiplayer, but that doesn't mean some features couldn't have been added to the offline side to make it more enjoyable. Like, you know, a skirmish mode to play against bots. That would've been nice. I don't get how earlier games had this, but DICE just decided to stop doing it all of the sudden. It would've been a godsend when the sign in service was acting up. The campaign could've done with some weapon customization or unlocks or something to make it worth playing more than once anyway.So overall, it's a really great game in the multiplayer side of things, and even still enjoyable in singleplayer. I would definitely recommend that everyone give it a try. It has definitely been one of the best experiences I've had in the gaming world.

TL;DR at bottomIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!8/10Recommended PurchaseA Night to Remember


Here we go. . . 
A Screenshot of Battlefield: Bad Company 2
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




Bad Company 2 is a first person shooter game created by DICE and published by EA in 2010. The game features both a team-based multiplayer mode and a singleplayer campaign. The singleplayer campaign has you playing as Marlowe, a member of an elite American special ops team. You start the game,however playing as Thomas Wyatt, coincidentally also a member of a U.S special ops team,though this time you play back in the WWII era instead of in the future. You start out going on a secret mission to meet up with a Japanese Scientist who wants to defect and claims to have valuable information on a new super weapon. Things quickly go to hell and your entire team is wiped out after the Japanese discover you and proceed to make you bear witness to the test firing of the weapon,killing you and your team.


Home sweet home. 
A Screenshot of Battlefield: Bad Company 2
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




You begin the real campaign after that and you start playing as Marlowe,though the campaign is in a futuristic setting now instead of the bleak hell of WWII. The campaign features 13 full levels with each one ranging from 10-20ish minutes to complete,with some more long or difficult missions being around 30-40 minutes at most. For the most part the missions are all quite linear,although they give you open fighting grounds to fill with corpses as you make your way to the objectives.If you came to Bad Co. 2 for a story that would blow your socks off you will be suprisingly (or maybe not suprisingly,depending on how you feel about Battlefield) dissappointed. The story isn't poorly made nor is it poorly done at all really. Problems arise when you have a story that is incredibly average and is only being held up by the unparalleled gunplay. When you get into the thick of fighting it's easy to get lost in the heavy smoke of the fresh gunpowder and the whump of your rifle as you mow down entire squads in your quest to save America from Soviet invasion.


Annihilation 
A Screenshot of Battlefield: Bad Company 2
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




Into the Fire . . . With Some Help The campaign may not be anything special but i'll be damned if this isn't one of the most fun MP modes I have played in quite a while. The destructibility is astoundingly fun to play with and actually has some serious strategic value. Enemy sniper hiding behind a window? 40MM Grenade launcher solves that real quick. Enemy soldiers crossing a bridge into your base? Blow that bridge to hell and back! Being able to just destroy pretty much anything at anytime you want is an incredible idea in both the campaign and the multiplayer. The multiplayer itself consists of 5 different game modes each with varying degrees of difficulty. The first one is Conquest,a mode where each team has a set amount of tickets,dying will of course drop this ticket total by 1 per death,and the goal is to drain the other teams tickets before they drain yours. There are also multiple flags you can hold that will give you a constant ticket drain if you hold the majority. Other than that you just need to kill them faster than they can kill you.The next mode is Rush,a gamemode where you have two teams,attackers and defenders each trying to attack or defend multiple M-COM stations respectively. Attackers are tasked with setting C4 charges on the stations then defending them until they explode. Defenders,of course are charged with defending the stations until they finally bring the attackers' ticket count to zero.After that you have Team Deathmatch which,if you have ever played a multiplayer FPS before, just consists two teams each trying to end the game with the most kills. Next you have squad rush which is just normal rush but with no vehicles,smaller maps,and a max of eight players.Finally there's onslaught,a co-op DLC mode where you try to play against AI and capture flags. Vehicles spawn at certain points and there are multiple levels of difficulty to fight against. Generally all the MP modes seem fairly balanced and there were no glaring problems with the mode that I noticed during regular play. The matchmaking system is completely broken and will either not find you a match,even though plenty are available,or it will put you in a match with just yourself; so make sure you just use server browser.The Multiplayer is what you really would be buying this game for as the campaign was pretty much overlooked due to more people wanting MP than SP.TL;DRAn excellent game for the price. Astoundingly well done MP component with an overwhelmingly average SP campaign. Solid gunplay and unparalled destructability make this a game you wont want to miss.If you enjoyed this writing and want to read more of such reviews,check out my steam curator page at Mudkips Gaming

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Where Battlefield 2 was about that slower paced Squad based Teamwork, Battlefield: Bad Company 2 went in the complete opposite direction. Sure if you work as a team you'll overcome and win as you'd expect, but the pace is ramped up and the craziness is all the way up to 11!The singleplayer campaign has it's moments, but as with any Battlefield game that has a singleplayer campaign it's not what you'll ultimately be buying the game for. It's the multiplayer - as it should be and as it always should be. Whereas the original Bad Company was tongue-in-cheek and entirely selfaware of how over the top the franchise was at times (as well as the FPS genre in a post-Modern Warfare world), Bad Company 2 tones it down slightly (much to my own personal disappointment). I personally didn't mind the Bad Company spinoff from the Battlefield series, it was it's own thing and that was entirely fine with me. However, it appears as if Bad Company 2 is almost ashamed of it's original brother and returns to a more 'grounded' root, and almost tries to ape Call of Duty: Modern Warfare's fast paced Michael Bay OTT action... while keeping a straight face.Which is a shame.However... that's not what you're interested in in this game... to the multiplayer!The multiplayer aspect offers you almost everything you'd ask for in a Battlefield game - big maps, crazy weapons, tons of Armor and memorible moments of madness. This was one of the first Battlefield games to really try and push the envelope visually as they ramped up the Frostbite Engine to a whole new level of insanity. I remember feeling 'My PC can actually play this?!' to great surprise and glee too.So don't undersell your PC if you're unsure on the specs. The minimum specs will still give you a good visual experience.As for the gameplay, I think this was my favourite. I can't really put my finger on what it was exactly, but everything just seemed to work well together. Teamwork, classes, weapons - land mines. Land Mines. C4. Land mines. Airstrike. Land minds. C4...OK, so it's the explosions. Planting landmines, hiding around the corner and giggling like a Japanese schoolgirl as that big burley tank came lumbering around the corner to go down the narrow street time and time again. Yup, it's the land mines. Buy this game.Plant land mines.Laugh like Japanese Schoolgirl.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												I've at least dabbled in all the Battlefield games from Battlefield 2 upwards, but I have to say that this is the best one for a fair number of reasons. To find out why follow me... I'll be reporting from inside the fight! (Races off towards distant towering explosions erupting over the war-shattered horizon, stubs toe, cries.)If you're after single player Bad Company 2 brings some fairly smart level design with a sharp, fairly witty script that approaches like a Shane Black movie. It's not screen-writing brilliance or anything, but it has a far greater sense of fun and playfulness than its increasingly tedious sequels and the latter Call of Duty games. No dark and gritty moping about here, purporting to show the 'horrors' of war whilst quivering with lust over the latest sniper scope attachment, nope. Just four Bro-Force men (or rather three and a mandatory smart-aleck quipping Shane Black staple) taking down the bad guys like out of some Kelly's Heroes meets Commando movie. So yeah, not genius, but fun. Battlefield 3's snooze-inducing 'arty' debriefing scenes framework nearly made me break my nose on the computer desk, so lethargic they made me. I cannot really recall Battlefield 4's at all. Plus the game is a lot less linear than subsequent outings, where you get to use the completely destructible scenery to its fullest advantage to forge new paths in completing a level.("The stretched twig of peace is at melting point...") Graphics! Well, they're very nice. Sure, Battlefield 3 & 4 have slightly shinier, more detailed graphics with slightly more convincing character animations and lens flare coo-worthy prettiness. But really, these graphics more than do the job. Dust clouds from descending helicopters, litter blowing in the streets, shockwaves rippling, shrapnel flying through the air... it's all here. And it won't tax your modern day computer too much neither. And there isn't too much going on to distract from the gunplay and everything runs smooth, so you won't be visually overwhelmed whilst trying to pick off the bad guys so much.And this game has the joint best audio of any game ever. The co-achiever of this award goes to The Long Dark, and its tremendously atmospheric sparse soundtrack and wonderful environmental sound. But Bad Company 2 has something magical called 'The War Tapes', activate it and feel like 1990's CNN war correspondent Peter Arnett fired by the NEWS CANNON of an Abraham Tank into the SOUNDS OF A WAR MIXED BY THE DERANGED PHIL SPECTOR HIMSELF. Ahem. Basically it's just a rather fantastic mix of panicky crackling intercom messages, wonderful bass-rumbling cannon fire and the sound of bullets zipping past your ears. You need headphones to really do it justice. ("...people here are very much bursting with war...")So, you all know the basics of how it plays, no doubt. But how's the multiplayer? Well, it's the best in the series. This is beautifully balanced shooter created before kill-streak bonuses and landfill-stuffing +0.2% shotgun-accuracy unlocks smothered fun like a big statty-based tidal wave of squinty misery. There's four classes performing the roles of assault, medic, anti-tank and recon sniper. The recon sniper is the smartest tweak of the set, as the game encourages snipers to move closer to the action with such toys as C4 and movement sensors. The game gives them fun close quarter pistols and ways to support the team from the front lines. You can also snipe too, and have fun doing it, but you can no longer prone. This encourages movement, and forces snipers to quit camping and instead rove the buildings of a battlefield, picking off hapless players and then fleeing the area as enraged victims bring the upper floors crashing down upon their noggin. Yes, crashing floors. Practically all the buildings in Bad Company 2 can be blown apart piece by piece until the entire edifice comes a-tumbling down in a avalance of masonry-mayhem. It makes for great tactical play too. Using a grenade launcher to create a new entrance point never gets old, especially if Johnny-Foe is caught on the other side of the impromptu door opening. Yup, by the end of the battle few structures remain unscathed. ("...this very much is a country about to blow up in it's own face." The maps are very good, with shout-outs going to Panama Canal, Arica Harbour and Oasis as to my mind the best three. I also have a fondness for the atmospheric snowy levels. The only maps I don't like are Harvest Day and Heavy Metal, which are vehicle dominated. I find it very hard to get a good footing on either of them, and the lack of cover makes trying to get around an abject misery. Not much room for tactical play either. Predictably, they seem to be the most popular on the servers. Gngh and argh.What else? Well, it all seems a bit more fluid and smoother than the latter Battlefields. Wiser and more knowledgable heads might nod knowingly and mutter the words, 'netcode', or something, but I've got no real idea why. All I know is it feels more fun to me. And I guess that's the important thing. SO. If you're itching to buy a military-themed multiplayer shooter with lots of vehicles and explosions and scenes unfolding like the best bits of Apocalypse Now, then get this one. It's pretty much the only one you'll need and is far less depressing than the 'mature' ponderous tosh forced on us nowadays. In Summary: COMPLETELY BANG! BAD COMPANY 2 IS SO ENTHUSIASTICALLY WAR IT'S BRINGING YOU ANOTHER TEAR ON THE FACE OF THE WORLD'S MOTHER. 9 / 10P.S: Apologies for the excess of The Day Today references.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Here's what I remember about the campaign: I couldn't beat it. It was really, really hard. The AI seemed too smart, too capable, too deadly. And then, because Windows 7 64-bit was giving me trouble at the time, I downgraded, switched back to good old Vista, and lo and behold, suddenly, I beat the campaign with no issues. Since then, I have played on Windows 7, which has none of the teething problems it used to, and not experienced this problem.Weird, right?I have no explanation for this. None whatsoever.The campaign is short--you know how people always accuse multiplayer campaigns of being like four hours long? Well, me, I generally play them in two to three times that much. Only a small handful of games have ever proven to me to be super short, and Bad Company 2 is one of them. It's not a particularly well-designed campaign, either. Fun, I guess, but limited. The multiplayer was where I spent all my time. Never before or since has a game gripped me as much. I'd be willing to argue it's the best multiplayer in the Battlefield series--it doesn't use that stupid web-based Battlelog like BF3 and BF4 do, after all.Other than a lack of maps--that were eventually added in, a lack of multiplayer modes (people only ever seem to play Rush or Conquest, a far cry from the dozens of multiplayer modes that ship with other games, like Unreal Tournament or Call of Duty), and a frequent re-use of map assets (which were first seen in BFBC1 and reused in BF3), it's just... the best. It's tweaked right, the classes feel balanced, and the maps themselves are my favorites. I wouldn't say everyone should play this game, but I will say that if you like team-based multiplayer shooters, Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is something you'll enjoy.The Vietnam expansion was pretty cool, by the way.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												The best Battlefield. The map design is excellent; it prioritizes fun engagements above all else. Maps are largely built around prefab, destructible, 2-3 floor buildings, which buffer the flow of combat and compartmentalize individual encounters. This means that you can actually breathe and make meaningful decisions in between all of the twitch-based watch-every-corner assaults. You know that segment in every battlefield scene where two soldiers duck behind cover and banter, using the moment of calm to rest and survey their surroundings before leaping back out guns blazing? This game is all about that moment. Front lines move back and forth in a perceivable way, you can get caught in epic holdouts with your squad, and buildings take a LOT of damage before they collapse, with each blown-out wall potentially changing your tactics. And despite how dynamic things get, you never burn out. Because you can breathe.Oh, and there are NO JETS, which means that A) Infantry can meaningfully engage every vehicle, B) no player has to  dedicate themself exclusively to countering air units, C) air units are easy to keep track of, and D) air combat remains cover-based and low-flying. The whole "battlefield" experience is much more tightly woven together as a result.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												BFBC2 can be considered as a 'scaled-down' BF game. It is simpler: maximum only 32 players per server , less weapons and attachments, less options.At the same time, some people do dislike having too many players on a server, prefer actually playing rather than spending time choosing and matching from too many weapons/attachment options and having too many complexities - in other words, wanting to play a 'simpler' BF, but still wanting a 'BF-ish' game and not COD or others.If you want to play a game and have fun, personally, I have a lot of fun with this game (I have and also play another seven BF games).At the time of writing, number of players online range from a few hundred to over a thousand. To check current numbers:http://steamcharts.com/app/24960To check where the servers are located:https://www.gametracker.com/search/bc2/US/?sort=3&order=DESCDo check at different times of the day as the population in servers drastically change (obviously), and just one 'snapshot view' won't tell you much about the online numbers and locations of where the players are.Depending on the location, some people may only have more distant servers to play on with higher pings - different people feel differently about higher pings. For me: I get to play BF4 on a high tick 60 or 120Hz server with 30 ping all the time, but at the same time I also really enjoy playing BFBC2 with a ping of 150.The above is a just a very brief summary of what the game is about - depending on what you are looking for and what you like, the choice is yours.(I'm not commenting on the campaign because I don't play campaigns)

Don't mind my few hours on Steam with this game, as I played another 15 hours on the version I have registered on Origin.Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is a 2010 first-person shooter video game developed by EA DICE. Released in 2010, this game still outdoes nearly every single other game out of the Battlefield-series, and nearly no-one knows why.The singleplayer is one to be played (though it is a little weird... played it 4 or more times and didn't really understood of what was going on), and the multiplayer has become more than friendly to new players, as there are multiple High-XP-servers on which you can unlock all the weapons within about 2 hours, depending on how you play. You do not need to have Origin started in order to play this game, which is another laaaaarge plus-point.Using Frostbite 1.5, the game looks decent as has good physics concerning the recoil of weapons and the handling of vehicles that are usable ingame.With the Vietnam DLC, it brings a more historical touch to the game, sadly without a singleplayer campaign, which I imagine would have been the cherry on top of the cake.Being both brutal and atmospheric at once, this game is a must-have for every Battlefield-fan out there, and a game to be played for every non-Battlefield-fan. ;)Did I already mention that Battlefield: Bad Company 2 does not require Origin? Because it doesn't  which is pretty cool if you ask me.

content:
Posted: March 1
												Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is a competitive multiplayer FPS with very simple enjoyable gameplay.It also might be the only current-gen/next-gen Battlefield game to not be stained by Electronic Art's greediness. Just wait before the franchise turns into a free-to-play game with micro-transactions and before it invades the Android platform.The community is still active even nowadays. And yet the game is still the most overlooked Battlefield of the franchise. Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed BF3 and BF4, but this game is a classic. Boasts more players than Hardline, doesn't require Origin, no Battlelog, no suppression, no premium.PROS :+ Very arcadiesh gameplay that features lots of destroyable buildings and such+ Love that it has a bullet drop mechanic so that snipers can't shoot from 8,000 miles away and not have to adjust+ Doesn't require Origin to play+ In-game servers browser and matchmaking system (no web browsing like BF3 BF4)+ No premium account, season pass or whatever you call it+ Doesn't have multiplayer map packs Call of Duty, feels like a complete game by itself+ No unlock purchase+ Melee killing people gives your their dogtag (ID) which permanently stays in your profile as a momento of lists of people you've disgraced, feels almost like an achievement that doesn't stop growing+ One amazing DLC that feels like a Total Conversion or a reskin of Battlefield in the Vietnam War era+ Winning objectives opens up further parts of the mapCONS :- No 64 players maps- No option to change the narrow field of view (default 65) except in the .ini document- Unlike Battlefield 2, Bad Company 2 features no mod- Bad Company 2 Vietnam servers are almost empty (if you're lucky you may find two active servers)Old doesn't mean obsolete!Forget about Battlefield 3 and 4 and be part of the Bad Company!TL;DR:9.0Great classic FPS that isn't corrupted by micro-transactions

												This game was released 2010. That is 6 years ago and we know what EA and Dice has given us after that. A lot of improvements, graphicly, Frostbite engine, Higher tick rate servers etc. + Graphic: The graphic is really nice and the gameplay feel very smooth. + Storyline: I wish I could have played Bad Company 1 as well because I do believe that it had a better story. However the actors and the comedy make this story to one of a kind. No doubt. + Frostbite engine: On Bad Company 1/2 they let you destroy much more enviorment than BF 3/4. Which is always fun+ Weapons: The weapon FEELS powerful. The sound are really nice. + Soundtrack: I really like how they added music to the game. It adds much more feeling to the game. - Multiplayer unbalanced maps: This problem still remains in Battlefield 3/4 as well. The map are too unbalanced. Which means on some maps, 8/10 times you etheir win hard or lose hard. There is no between. This cannot be blamed on the teams. It is a map issue. - There is hardly any rest time in multiplayer. When you lose a base in rush. It takes you 10 seconds and then the enemy are nearby the next objective. Very intense and I disslike it. Personal opinion- During the story line you run a lot. On Battlefield 3/4 they leave you with much more action, less running. I put it as a negative thing however it is a personal preference. - Story line bugs. There are a lot of them. CPU that won't die. Terrain bugs. etc. It is not something that RUIN the story but everytime it happens. It will remind you that it exist. I won't compare this game to Battlefield 3/4 so I say as a game in general 8/10

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I bought this game by accident. When it was on 75% sale, I bought 3 or 4 copies of it to resell later for TF2 keys, and then sell them on the steam market for profit (yea, I know that's lame). But instead of buying all of them as gifts, I accidentally bought one copy for myself. And now, when I finally got a new computer and can play it normally, I can say that I don't regret it at all.I heard a lot of♥♥♥♥♥♥about EA and origin, so I didn't expect much from this game, yet it turned out to be really addicting and surprisingly fun.I'm not going to say too much about the campaign because this game is much more multiplayer-oriented. It's pretty good for getting a grasp on how the game mechanics and weapons work, but I didn't like it TOO much. The plot and characters seem ok, but actual combat is a bit frustrating because your squadmates are downright dumb and you'll  have to kill 90% of the bad guys yourself (another reason for that is that they usually wait for YOU to go first and take all the fire while they sit in some cover). Duh, at least they are immortal, because it would be EXTREMELY frustrating if the game would restart when someone from your squad is killed. And finally - the enemies usually outnumber you by 4-5 times, do the US military commanders really expect THAT much from 4 guys? Unlikely.The multiplayer, on the other hand, is really awesome. You'll probably get stomped in the beginning though, because crucial unlocks for your soldier are received after not too much, but noticable playtime - for instance, in the beginning your medic loadout will be MG+pistol, that's all; medkit and defibrillator is easily unlocked later, but still kinda frustrating when your teammates expect you to throw some first aid at them and you, well, CAN'T. That being said, at least most WEAPONS you get at the start are pretty good, most notably sniper rifle and assault rifle.The overall balance is great, no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ specializations (not meaning to start a flame war, but CoD's "martyrdom" comes to mind), no OP weapons (in my opinion; many people seem to hate carl gustav AT, but I have no problem with that), and each of 4 classes can contribute to the team - medic heals and revives, assault can use smoke grenades to cover his teammates and gives ammo boxes, engie repairs tanks and recon, well, can at least spot and throw motion sensors (btw, the spotting mechanic is really good, allows you to communicate with your team + if you're being shot by a camper, instead of frantically trying to write something in chat, you can simply press "q" and your bloodthirsty teammates will kill him).Vehicles are also great, a tank in skilled hands with an engineer repairing it can be devastating, but can be just as  easily destroyed with some teamwork.The community... Let's just say it's ok, like in any typical multiplayer game. Even then, the chat takes up a small area in the corner of the screen, you can very well ignore it (I haven't met any people who use microphones after 55 hrs of total playtime). But generally most people are willing to cooperate (medics revive and heal when you ask for it, assaults drop ammo boxes etc.).Overall, this is a great game with a lot of variety, never gets boring and has surprisingly never made me mad even when I got killed a lot. Worth buying, wait for a sale if you don't want to spend too much money on games.

Posted: May 7, 2016
												So... I have written very few reviews on Steam and am not the greatest at them, but here goes.                  Battlefield Bad Company Two: I myself have been playing Battlefield since 1942. I own a copy of every battlefield there is. I own physical copies of Battlefied 1942, Vietnam and Modern WArfare (Not the greatest of the series but the first to hit concoles) I also own a copy of Battlefield 3 on Origin ( 4 was a complete joke due to EA forcing Dice to rush the production in under a year, thus I speak not of it).                  Battlefield Bad Company 2 comes with a high reccomendation from myself as a veteran of the series. Coupled with graphics that have aged extremely well over the past 6 years, solid gameplay and amazing destruction for its time. This game offers an experience no other Battlefield has yet to do. With a sound engine that supports 7.1 Surround, graphics that look and still feel real, and large maps with balanced classes and vehicles. This game is still to date my favourite of the series.                   Now for the sad part... Battlefield Bad Company 2 is slowly dieing out. Servers are become ghost towns as players are drawn to the c**p that EA forces its development teams to pump out. I beg this of thee, please purchase this game, come experience it with me, bring back the life that was one so bright, join us in keeping this game aloft in our quest for giant and beyond fun battles. Show EA that a great game does not come from its amount of DLC. But from the love of a lasting community that is will to pay for a single product, and continue to play it even decades after its release. Help us keep this game going, come join us... The Battlefield awaits you.

												One of the best games I've ever playedSingleplayer: the Story was "okay" i suppose since it was kind of dull unlike the Call of Duty series which have fairly decent storylines. I think they should put a bit more time into developing the Singleplayer, at least as much time as they have spent on the multiplayer.Multiplayer: It seems to me that the Multiplayer was really worked on in this game because it was more refined and more interesting than the Singleplayer. There is a great variety of weapons and weapon addons in the multiplayer for you to chose from. There are also different classes that focus on your playing style. Suppose you want to kill people with a sniper rifle. You can easily choose the recon class that allows you to have a sniper rifle, a pistol, Mortar strike and a motion censor.You can also add a red dot scope on to your Sniper Rifle for close range combat. Not only that but there are class perks that really brings your playing style out. Suppose you want to do a lot of damage as recon, you can unlock and equip the Magnum Bullets perk to maximize your damage. I would highly recommend buying this game, it will not dissapoint you. Rating: 9/10

content:
Posted: October 18, 2011
												Shortly; Battlefield Bad Company 2 was over my expectations. Even though my expectations weren't set that high, DICE really delivered yet another solid shooter. It's a great game for anyone who enjoyed the previous Battlefield games. The long version;  In perspective to the Battlefield series;  I know many people complain about this game, and I've even heard DICE themselves say that it wasn't the best they've created. And on the last point, I need to agree, it's not the best game in the Battlefield series, not according to me. I've been along since the beginning (1942) and played all the games released in the series. The most unappealing to me was the 2142, somehow I couldn't accept the futuristic side of a Battlefield game. That said, Battlefield 2 is to me the best game in the series (Yes, even now with 3 and 4 out.), to me, it was a more ground-breaking game than the rest of the series later have been. But, I shouldn't speak to highly of it, a big part of it now is nostalgia I've got to admit.  Singleplayer;  I played BFBC1 through the main story, and though the missions and all maybe weren't the best. I liked it, it was fun, and for BFBC2 I have to say the same. Note though that it was the characters and the story that sold me into it. If you don't appreciate the humoristic side of it, I don't think it's that much to aim for.  Multiplayer;  Here is where it excels (Remember, I only speak for my opinion.);  I didn't get the chance to play that much multiplayer on BFBC1 so I can't compare it much to that. However, teaming up with some of your friends and jump into a squad with them, and play tactical (Okay, we didn't take it that serious, but we still teamworked.) I don't see how you can't like it. It's a great FPS, it's a really great FPS. The majority of the maps feels designed with care. The classes are fairly balanced, even though you'll be swearing alot about snipers taking you down a little bit too often. (This of course varied from patch to patch.). And the vehicle play was a treat. With the Frostbite engine, everything looks great.  The level and weapons system is neatly created, even though it took almost to fast to unlock all the weapons considering how many levels there were left after having them all. Alternatively, you can see this as maybe there could be some more weapons thrown in the game.  On the bad side though;   The team-balance feature didn't really worked as you wanted it too. (Some of the options we're up to the servers admins, but not everything. And besides, it's not like there's always an admin online to help with the issues at hand.) If one team managed to claim a essential capture/spawn-point early in the game, it was not unusual it quickly became a so called base♥♥♥♥♥♥game. And then you're stuck in the rest of the game at your homebase not daring to even peak around the corner because then you'll get a snipers bullet between your eyes. But find a good server (Or host your own!) and admins can help with this issue, at least a little bit.  I myself tried to tell my team to give them one of the spawning points if it were my team that had captured them all, to give them a fair chance, and it worked at least sometimes.  I also have to give credits to the server system, it is, according to me even better than the sequel, Battlefield 3. I rarely had problem adding servers to my favorites or joining friends in just a click and getting into the same squad as them.  Bottom line; If you liked the previous Battlefield games, I don't see why you wouldn't like this one. It's a different feeling sure. But according to me, that difference was a nice change to freshen up the series. Sometimes I even preferred to boot it up instead of BF3. It's a game I warmly recommend. And there's a numerous ways to experience it, you can play really fast and all-out-action, or you can just lurk around the small ways to find around the enemies trying to take them down one by one, it's really easy to just jump in and press play, for 20 minutes, or 5 hours.

Posted: October 7, 2015
												Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is a 2010 first-person shooter video game developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts (EA). It is a direct sequel to Battlefield: Bad Company and is part of the Battlefield game series. The game is primarily a squad-level first-person shooter based in a contemporary modern warfare setting. Additionally, the game includes a single-player campaign, where the player re-assumes the role of Preston Marlowe, the protagonist of the original game. The game's Frostbite 1.5 engine now allows for destructible environments. Multiplayer maps, which allow for five different game modes, contain a wide selection of vehicles, aircraft and emplacements. While Bad Company 2 is primarily a first-person shooter, it follows other games in the series by allowing the player to control certain vehicles, including ATVs, APCs, tanks, and helicopters. On foot, players are given access to a variety of real-world small arms such as assault rifles and machine guns. Players can also jump, crouch, and sprint. Bad Company 2 heavily emphasizes destructible environments. Large sections of most buildings can be destroyed by explosives, and some walls and fences break down under barrages of bullets, with the game's physics engine realistically simulating the destruction. Bad Company 2 features a story-driven single-player campaign. For most of the narrative, the player takes control of Preston Marlowe, one of the members of the titular "Bad Company". Multiplayer is class-based, with four classes: Assault, Engineer, Medic, and Recon. Each class has a variety of unique weapons and equipment, and serves a specific role in combat. There are also some weapons that can be used by any class, such as pistols and shotguns. Each class gains experience and levels up separately. Overall I rate this game a 8/10 although, the campaign may not be the best it's the multiplayer that makes me play this game. After 5 years there are still lots of people playing on the servers and it's very addicting to keep playing until you've got every single unlock in the game. I really recommend this game I am absolutely 100% sure that it will not disappoint you in anyway!.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2012
												This game is a real piece of work, not necessarily in a bad way though. The Singleplayer experience is okay, its got a pretty decent story spanning ww2 and modern day war scenarios, even has you crash a satellite and recover its black box.It's version of the Battlefield Frostbite engine allows for completly destroying buildings with c4, instead of the more modern one seen in battlefield 3 and even battlefield 4 where only bits and pieces of buildings can be destroyed(not counting the specific scripted events in battlefield 4 where you can demolish a skyscraper or blow up a dam).It's Multiplayer aspect is a bit lacking, there is no proning, there is a very bad latency problem which only seems to clear up if you run this game with a medium to top tier computer and wookies (ghillie suit snipers) dominate most maps.Its business model is a bit bad, as it has 2 DLC, one adds a new map and weapons and thats fine, but the other unlocks all the top tier weapons for each class, or rather provides you with exact replicas.Note that the weapons which are unlocked are top tier but aren't necessarily the best weapons in the game.Overall even though this game like all games has its flaws and some are worse than others, it's still worth looking into and playing with friends.Personally find the "have your friend take the uav and put a ♥♥♥♥ton of c4 on it and slam it into the M-COM" to be quite enjoyable.As this is as always a personal opinion i'd give this game a 7/10, its a pretty decent game without game breaking bugs worth referencing, just slight inconviniences.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												As of January 6th, 2016, the game is still active. There's over a dozen full servers depending on what region you queue in.That being said, the pings that are displayed in the server browser and your in-game ping do not match up. Whatever ping you see in the server browser, double it, and that will be your ping in-game.Most of the people who are left playing this live in countries with awful internet latency. I think the average ping of an adversary is somewhere around 180, which makes it frustrating to play because your bullets will seem like they don't exist, and it will seem like you're dying in one or two hits.Survive up until rank 15 and it becomes playable, since you unlock magnum rounds. At least then your bullet damage will increase and the few bullets that register will be worth more damage.The game is still largely the same. I owned it on PS3 and I wanted to give it a go on PC since it was $5. I wouldn't buy this for $20, but it was an alright price for what I got it for. It's still fun. Annoying with the whole ping thing, but fun nonetheless.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2012
												This game is a real piece of work, not necessarily in a bad way though. The Singleplayer experience is okay, its got a pretty decent story spanning ww2 and modern day war scenarios, even has you crash a satellite and recover its black box.It's version of the Battlefield Frostbite engine allows for completly destroying buildings with c4, instead of the more modern one seen in battlefield 3 and even battlefield 4 where only bits and pieces of buildings can be destroyed(not counting the specific scripted events in battlefield 4 where you can demolish a skyscraper or blow up a dam).It's Multiplayer aspect is a bit lacking, there is no proning, there is a very bad latency problem which only seems to clear up if you run this game with a medium to top tier computer and wookies (ghillie suit snipers) dominate most maps.Its business model is a bit bad, as it has 2 DLC, one adds a new map and weapons and thats fine, but the other unlocks all the top tier weapons for each class, or rather provides you with exact replicas.Note that the weapons which are unlocked are top tier but aren't necessarily the best weapons in the game.Overall even though this game like all games has its flaws and some are worse than others, it's still worth looking into and playing with friends.Personally find the "have your friend take the uav and put a ♥♥♥♥ton of c4 on it and slam it into the M-COM" to be quite enjoyable.As this is as always a personal opinion i'd give this game a 7/10, its a pretty decent game without game breaking bugs worth referencing, just slight inconviniences.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Battlefield is a great series, don't get me wrong on that. But with all EA titles... there are kickers that will make you think twice.The game is the best when you look at it from a technical standpoint. Blow up cover that enemies might be hiding behind... that has to be the most satisfying thing to do. No more camping is to be seen when the whole building is gone.As the game progressed through it's cycle, it seems to be left in a buggy state. Almost by reason. Fences and grass can be seen in houses, coming out of the floor. After countless hours, I had only found this later on. Maybe a new title had something to do with it?No real point in getting the game. Just like Nuclear Dawn, the game has come and gone. There's no real community, it's moved on to BF3, now BF4. Look at this game as a collector's item, nothing more. Story for single player isn't worth the time. Quick and painless, get's you ready for multiplayer which no longer exists.7.5/10

Damn straight you'll be pressing that "buy" button any time soon.Bad Company 2 is all about teamwork, blowing stuff up and earning those shiney medals and lots and lots of explosions. Now get movin', trooper!

												The singleplayer is fun but the multiplayer is the real experience.One of the better FPS in my opinion, it sets itself apart by focusing more on the teamwork aspect of multiplayer. It does this via the class system implemented in the game, this allows teams to work efficiently if everyone picks the corresponding class and attributes to it. content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												I've only played the single player campaign (twice) so I can only comment on that. I thought it was pretty enjoyable. The gunplay very tight and satisfying, the vehicles fun to drive, and lots of weapons to discover and switch around.The COD games and BF games all have the same approach to their single player campaigns where you feel like your hand is being held and you're moving from setpiece to setpiece. Everything is so staged, linear and orchestrated. But as long as you choose to accept that, this game is pretty fun. You can up the difficulty if you feel it's too accomodating.the Bad Company games are beloved offshoot of Battlefield because the characters that accompany you during the campaign are fun to listen to, and the story is sometimes funny. I like the idle conversations that take place if you stand around with them, too.In short, definitely worth getting for the single player, if you don't mind the "theme park ride" campaign.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Well balanced shooter-no weapon or class is best. Vehicles such as gunships aren't indestructible, but with teamwork and cooperation (Going solo in a tank or chopper isnt as rewarding as having teammates by your side) , they aren't useless either. Maps are pretty well designed. Some of the maps for rush could be built better for defending teams (eg taking MCOMs out of destructible buildings) but none will disappoint. Some maps are designed solely for one game mode, while others are made for all game modes. The latter works suprisingly well.The game looks fab, and even rivals BF3 in some areas (COLOUR). The destruction in BC2 still stellar and watching buildings topple never gets old. And its more than just eye candy-its always modifying a map, in terms fo where you can/cant go. Its a big part of gameplay.Apart from the single player campaign (which isn't awful, but not amazing either), there's little thats bad about BFBC2. The multiplayer community is still thriving so go buy it now!And on a side note, no god-awful Origin or Battlelog b0llocks!

Posted: June 28, 2015
Arguably the best Battlefield gameWhy?- It is not that casual of a shooter as the other Battlefield games, as there are not that many gadgets that make it easy to kill other players. For example, the Javelin and remote mortar.- The different classes had the most appropriate equipment to their class and it made sense. Assualt players gave out ammo and had C4. Supoprt players had the role of dropping health and reviving people.- Recoil and bullet spread played a key factor in this game. For example, firing an automatic gun for a long duration of time meant that it would be quite difficult to kill the enemy.- The map design in this game is well designed so that the game modes flow well and the change in the dynamic of battle is apparent a team gets the upper hand- If one were to invest time into playing this game then the player would feel like they have been challenged and rewarded/content with the game.Therefore I highly recommend getting this game as it is the most rewarding experience and it requires the most skill :)

content:
Posted: March 31
												For some reason, it seems like it's really hard for EA and DICE to replicate the raw beauty of Bad Company 2. Or maybe they're just lazy. Campaign To quote Anthony Gallegos, "It was a blast!" The writing was very good, and there was a perfect mixture of maturity and humor. The only problem I really had was the overall short length of it, about 3-5 hours max. Other than that, I 100% recommend this game's campaign! Multiplayer To be honest, the maps were a bit smaller than usual (I would've preferred something like Battlefield 4's Siege of Shanghai), and as far as I know, there are sadly no jet fighters to fly around in, but I can assure you, that does not make the multiplayer any less fun or enjoyable.  Vietnam  Honestly, I was rather disappointed by the expansion pack. Even now, EA\DICE are presenting it as something that expands on the Bad Company 2 experience, but instead, what I found was a short list of maps. "But, but Tykylo! Itz Viatnahm! Dat meanz all of the pack's sinz r washd away, u fooking idiut! Y shuld we lizten to u, anywayz, u hav a CoD picture on ur prophile!!"  No, the Vietnam setting does not magically fix that problem, and attacking my profile pic does not qualify as constructive criticism. "U foking idiut, Im dun wit u!" Okay, bai.  Final Verdict This is a pretty tough one, because I personally love this game for all it is, but I don't want to get too biased about it. Overall, the Bad Company series has had a good reputation, and this one deserves a 8.9/10 from me. Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is basically Battlefield 4 but better. Get this one and the first Bad Company if you're interested. leave the newer Battlefield games to rot.

												BUENO: Definitivamente la mejor campaña que he jugado (en juegos bélicos). Tiene una buena historia, buenos graficos y sobre todo bastante detalle. Durante la campaña te encontraras con un sinfin de maneras de morir si lo juegas en las dificultades superiores. Habra momentos que si te quedas afk los personajes de tu patrulla comenzaran a charlar sobre temas cotidianos y graciosos como viajes de pesca, momentos incomodos al preguntar a tu comandante afroamericano, de peliculas muy conocidas, etc. Los personajes tienen actitudes y personalidades muy realistas y cada uno posee su toque personal de encanto. Si lo que buscas es una gran campaña te recomiendo este juego.MALO: El online....si asi es, el online a pesar de haber sido de renombre en el pasado, hoy ya tiene muy pocos servidores en linea y muy poca cantidad de jugadores, para encontrar un servidor con usuarios deberas cambiar los filtros de busqueda, pero nada que te impida una gran partida si la encuentras. El ambiente: a pesar de que dine que la campaña esta muy bien lograda hay....una pequeña cuestion, las casas. Son todas iguales por dentro..pero cuando digo iguales, es que son iguales...puede que por fuera parescan distintas pero si las miras en detalle veras que tambien son parecidas.RESUMEN:*Buena campaña, misiones muy emocionantes y adictivas*Online con pocos servers y jugadores*Ambientes elaborados, salvo por las casas.*COMPRALO!!!

												Simply put, the best multiplayer fps experience I've ever had. It was pure fun all along for the 300 hours or more I put into this game. Contrary to a lot of other fps, or any other battlefield game for the matter, I never really felt frustrated playing bad company 2. It was always fun, fast paced and never felt linear. content:
Posted: May 25, 2011
												In my opinion this game is currently (2011) the most enjoyable first person shooter on the market. If your computer can handle the graphics (they're intense) than you will not be disappointed. Although some may prefer the mindless fast-paced killing that exists in the Call of Duty Modern Warfare franchise, I find that this game provides a much more fulfilling experience. It requires more skill and foresight to fully enjoy, but if you are willing to put the time and effort (it takes patience - not running and gunning) into learning how to play you will appreciate the difference in gameplay and style. Although there is a single-player campaign, this game is primarily a multiplayer game. The single player campaign is mediocre but enjoyable (nothing like COD's excitement) but the multiplayer is where the game really shines. The fully destructible environments create an experience where every match can be different and you can surprise your opponents at the flip of a coin. 10/10 stars.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												JUST a great experience. That's ALL!Battlefield Bad Company 2 (BBC2) is a normal shooter military game. I had to play a shooter for years because of my strategy game taste and I decided to see where things had come. Well, the game is good. I think the multiplayer part, these games were designed for, is even better.Electronic Arts as always has made pretty good job on the graphics sector. The guns are pretty good. The soldiers' figures, the environment like trees, rocks, grass or whatever. The sounds are very normal in comparison with reality. Explosions, gun sounds, soldiers' voices, helicopter and plane sounds, all of them great.The story mode is weird. You continue to fight against the foes to find a secret weapon. A plane with cloak ability containing a great EMP pulse weapon of some sort. One gets another like a team when someone tries to go away from the cause saying that all finished. It's not bad , but NOT real anyway... lolLet's go to the point... GUNS and GUN fights. You'll have much gun play here. You'll find the one suited to your needs. Weapons with different aiming, precision, firepower, ammo, and reload times. I personally liked the heavy machine guns with the precision scopes even if without the scopes were more natural. Have you ever seen a very precised machine gun? NOoooooo. Can you carry an MG-3 with 200 rounds or an M60 with 500 rounds. They both weight about 10 kg WITHOUT the rounds. And you can use them almost as snipers do. Or you can move along with a scope in your eye.... LOL.. Totally fake. Or maybe you are a SUPER soldier.... Anyway.. It's fun because it's a game. Another point you won't like is RPG's or missile launchers.They are totally inaccurate and a tank needs 2 or more to die. This is an issue because you'll find yourself completely pinned down and you will be unable to do anything sometimes. With those weapons you fight tanks and helicopters, yeah you read right, helicopters. There is even a level that you have to do with two helies at the same time. You have some missile launchers at the borders of a base, but as they have guided missiles, the helies can avoid them. And at the same time you have infantry on your back, GREAT or HELL? The ONLY way to get down those helies was running among the ruins for cover and shoot with my OWN missile launcher. And everyone of them needs 2-3 shots to die, totally unnatural. The only weapon that fullfills its promise is the great sniper weapon. But this one fires Km far away. So, GOOD gun play but totally fake game.As much for the environment. Feeling like you are in a battlefield is NOT an easy case. So EA made everything destructable. Almost everything can be destroyed. You walk among the ruins and there are gas barrels or FULL tanks of trucks in the level. If you shoot at them they blow up. If you shoot at anything with heavy weapons it will be destroyed, buildings too.ONLY rocks and terrains is inpenetrable and undestructable. Another thing a player likes but it's totally unreal is that the same soldies can drive trucks, helies, ATVs, to be a gunner on them, drive a TANK with BOTH AT shells and against personnel. I mean OK, you HAVE to be a SUPER soldier. Am I playing Battlefield or Return to Castle Wolfenstein, Duke Nukem or Crysis? Has anyone of you played Super Trench Attack? If NOT search some walkthrough videos till the training and with it. You'll laugh so MUCH... You are the guy! The ONLY hero we have!So, after so .... much reality in this game and with great explosions and gun play I have to say it's JUST a great experience. That's ALL!

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Unbalanced and inconsistent. To start off, I'm not great at shooters but I enjoy them for the competiton. This game though, the multiplayer makes me upset. Most servers advertise "No spawn camping" and "Don't use X weapon if team size less than Y". Sure it may sound good but when you spend a total of 3.5 seconds alive and the remainder waiting to respawn, you tend to get salty. Another thing that I don't like, but I understand why it's in place, is limits of how many of each class be in a match. It makes it really unfair when the defenders can camp buildings all as snipers but attackers aren't allowed to have any snipers at all! It feels like everyones weapon is stronger than yours when it takes a clip an a half of consistent hits to kill them but they just need 2. The cover system is aesthetic considering most covers can be shot through and the ones that can't can either be destroyed or are too short to actually serve as cover. The only populated servers are repatative. You gain better equipment as you rank up, so higher ranking players will be more accurate, deal and take more damage and have, overall, a better chance at being sucessful.Overall, this game can be fun, provided you get into a good server and the other players are a somewhat similar rank to you and you learn every nook of each map. If you like shooters for campers and dying, you'll like this. If you like shooters for gameplay that's based mostly on skill, maybe not so much.

												Whenever I'm playing a multiplayer match in Bad Company 2, I feel like I'm part of a large scale battle, not some small skirmish like most online shooters. The maps are huge and make for great battles. I don't really get upset about my K/D either, because Im really only focusing on taking points or completing objectives for the team. The destruction physics are beautiful and work well for strategy too, for example, sniper in tower pinning your squad down? Easy fix, just blow up the tower. Bad Company 2 is easily the best battlefield game ever made.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2011
												The multiplayer is such a comprehensive FPS. The game play is of very high quality FPS grade. There are many guns with varied uses that actually feel like they each have their own feel to them. The class system and the perks are balanced so well that you really can equally enjoy everyone of them. The maps are spectacular vistas to behold. They are massive and extensive, but at the same time it is bearable to get around. The graphics are simply gorgeous and you need to make sure you have an adequate graphics card to run it. In comparison to the competing FPS games out there, such as COD Black Ops, it just completely blows them out of the water because of its depth, visual glory, and cohesive mesh of vehicular, FPS, and teamwork elements that COD could never accentuate. I highly recommend this game!

												For me, this game was one of the most exciting and most enjoyable games in my gaming history. Although I have not played the multiplayer online yet due to nobody playing it anymore, the storyline was the most fun and gripping of which I have ever experienced.What made my experience good?For a starter the characters were thought out very well and were reallistic and had a proper personality behind them.Secondly the storyline had a sense of unknowing behind it, unlike other games similar; this one used a well made sound to create a sense of fear un unknowing in the player.
