												A realistic shooter with high quality graphics and game play. The single player story line is okay but only lasts about 6 too 8 hours the first time through. Multiplayer is where this game really shines with huge battles consisting of over 30 players you can blow the crap out of each other in four different game modes on a slurry of maps. Hardly anyone uses a mic so don't expect much co-operation from your team-mates though unless you're part of a clan or guild. I've logged far more hours on this game then any other and paid the full price of 60 dollars when it came out, completely worth it. Since then I've bought five additional copies ranging in price from 6.80 to 60.00 dollars for friends and family. It now retails for about 20.00 dollars and is completely worth it. Battlefield 3 will be coming out soon though so keep that in mind (if it's not already that is).

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												I really love class-based multiplayer games (like Team Fortress 2 -- actually going all the way back to the Team Fortress mod for quakeworld), so Bad Company 2 really hits that perfect spot for me when it comes to first-person shooter style games.  The graphics are beautiful, and the realism is pretty amazing.  This is definitely one of, if not the only, game that I might keep a copy of Windows around to play since Valve ported all the Source engine-based games to Linux.  This any maybe Battlefield 4, if I ever decide to buy it.That said, it throws in a touch of RPG, forcing you to play hours and hours of gameplay to "level up" your soldier so you can be competitive in both single-player AND multiplayer games.  If I hadn't pre-ordered it and had it the day it came out, I could have seen myself getting angry about not having the same weapons available to other players, and it did cause me to only ever play Recon class (sniper, basically) because I never had a chance to level any other class up while trying to keep up as the class I really enjoyed best.In the end, though, I had a lot of fun playing.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												Bad Company 2 was my first game of the Battlefield series. I used to play it a lot on the PS3.Battlefield 3 was one of the reasons why I bought a gaming PC, which turned to be my new main platform, After over 200 hours in both Battlefield 3 and 4 I decided to pick up Bad Company 2 on Steam, because it was on sale.Now I remember why I stopped playing Battlefield 4 so suddenly - The series had it's peak with the Bad Company games.Bad Company 2 is currently the best version of Battlefield you can play on the PC. - No Origin - No Battlelog (Server List in Browser / starting your game via browser)- No prone (less campers)- Best Destruction in any Battlefield game- Most enjoyable weapons and vehicle balance in any Battlefield game- Bad Company games have a funny and entertaining campaign mode (much better than the 08/15 scripted ones in BF3 and BF4)- The hitboxes and "time to kill" feels more reasonable compared to newer Battlefield games- Still a beautiful game / you don't really see that this game is over 5 years old.And most important: This is the last game of the BF franchise that features a proper Rush mode!Yes BF3 and BF4 still have a Rush game mode, but it's very poorly done. Unbalanced and soul-less 1:1 conquest map slices.EA goes the "wrong way" (in the perspective of us gamers) with the Battlefield Series. The best way to voice your opinion is to buy Bad Company 2 and let EA know, that you would love the classic Battlefield experience back.Maybe they will listen some day, I doubt it...

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												No Origin Required. 10/10PROS.-Does not require use of the EA Origin game launcher-The last Battlefield where I can actually remember the characters from the story-Looks very good and runs very well on Frostbite game engine-Very fun and destructive multiplayer (Blowing things up, knocking down buildings, vehicle combat, etc.)-Smooth gunplay-Mod support-People in this game actually work together compared to more recent Battlefield titles-Well-written storyline, with the returning characters from the original Bad Company-Very intense unscripted multiplayer battles with some epic destruction mechanicsCONS.-Uses way too outdated (in my opinion) Punkbuster anticheat, which is also somewhat buggy sometimes and can get you randomly kicked from multiplayer games for no reason. VAC would be much nicer.-When playing it for the first time, expect some FPS drops for some reason, as this happens to many people when first launching the game-Missing some essential elements from video/interface settings (such as FOV slider, HUD customization, etc.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Played BC:1 back in the day and have always missed the simplicity and fun factor, especially after playing BF3/BF4. I never played BC:2 until now and wasn't sure how it would compare. About 2 minutes into my first game, equipped with the basic M24, I sniped the gunner out of the chopper that was lighting up our team. This is almost an impossible shot when playing BF3/4, in BC:2 it's not quite as 'sim' like and makes it that much more fun. After that I was hooked.BC:2, as many will tell you, is the last great Battlefield for so many reasons. No more grinding for (or buying $$) the best guns! This game is all about skill, and if you are reasonably experienced with FPS games you will play competitively from level 1.This game is so much more balanced than BF3/BF4, and best of all NO Origin! The only DLC you can buy (other than the camo pack) is Vietnam, which I picked up because of the great reviews, but I'd skip it. It's online only and the servers are empty. The main game however has dozens of full servers as of 11/30/14. For $5 this is an easy purchase.

												I never liked the Battlefield series but this one is very fun. It's an older game but give they you more features than the newer Battlefield games don't have. Being able to blow up buildings until nothing is left is a great experiance. I don't care too much for modern shooters but this one is actually quiet decent. It has multiple game modes that are all very fun and balanced classes. This game does have a handful of guns which you earn through different classes that unlock through points. They have a Vietnam DLC that I highly recommend buying it's very fun and vintage feeling. There aren't so many maps or guns but the DLC is very fun if your into the whole WW2 aspect. As for servers the modern side has hundreds of servers and most of them are full. On the other hand the WW2 is a different story there are dozens of servers but only two or three are being used. There are High-XP servers you can join if your looking to speed through the game otherwise most are normal.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Played BC:1 back in the day and have always missed the simplicity and fun factor, especially after playing BF3/BF4. I never played BC:2 until now and wasn't sure how it would compare. About 2 minutes into my first game, equipped with the basic M24, I sniped the gunner out of the chopper that was lighting up our team. This is almost an impossible shot when playing BF3/4, in BC:2 it's not quite as 'sim' like and makes it that much more fun. After that I was hooked.BC:2, as many will tell you, is the last great Battlefield for so many reasons. No more grinding for (or buying $$) the best guns! This game is all about skill, and if you are reasonably experienced with FPS games you will play competitively from level 1.This game is so much more balanced than BF3/BF4, and best of all NO Origin! The only DLC you can buy (other than the camo pack) is Vietnam, which I picked up because of the great reviews, but I'd skip it. It's online only and the servers are empty. The main game however has dozens of full servers as of 11/30/14. For $5 this is an easy purchase.

												Simply put, the best multiplayer fps experience I've ever had. It was pure fun all along for the 300 hours or more I put into this game. Contrary to a lot of other fps, or any other battlefield game for the matter, I never really felt frustrated playing bad company 2. It was always fun, fast paced and never felt linear. You can see players from across the map if you look carefully and that's something I liked about this game. The maps were nice, not too tight, not too big and all around really well balanced. There was always a lot of action going on too. The squad death match mode was the only squad death match mode in a battlefield game that I ever felt was balanced and fun. I played other battlefield games before that and Battlefield 3 and 4, both for more than 300 hours, and I can tell you BC2 Fun Factor was off the charts compared to those other titles.Hope DICE comes out with another gem like this in a near future.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Unbalanced and inconsistent. To start off, I'm not great at shooters but I enjoy them for the competiton. This game though, the multiplayer makes me upset. Most servers advertise "No spawn camping" and "Don't use X weapon if team size less than Y". Sure it may sound good but when you spend a total of 3.5 seconds alive and the remainder waiting to respawn, you tend to get salty. Another thing that I don't like, but I understand why it's in place, is limits of how many of each class be in a match. It makes it really unfair when the defenders can camp buildings all as snipers but attackers aren't allowed to have any snipers at all! It feels like everyones weapon is stronger than yours when it takes a clip an a half of consistent hits to kill them but they just need 2. The cover system is aesthetic considering most covers can be shot through and the ones that can't can either be destroyed or are too short to actually serve as cover. The only populated servers are repatative. You gain better equipment as you rank up, so higher ranking players will be more accurate, deal and take more damage and have, overall, a better chance at being sucessful.Overall, this game can be fun, provided you get into a good server and the other players are a somewhat similar rank to you and you learn every nook of each map. If you like shooters for campers and dying, you'll like this. If you like shooters for gameplay that's based mostly on skill, maybe not so much.

												This is one of the best battlefields you can play next to BF2 and 2142. The campaign is pretty good and the multiplayer is amazing. The game runs pretty decent even on a crap PC, and the ping is alright on the majority of servers. I recommend playing this with a friend(s) on MP so it's 10x better. The MP has tons of stuff like attack (and transport) helis, tanks, cars, jetskis, ATV's you name it, it's there. Game also lacks hackers even for it being 4 years old, rarely see hackers ever. For 20 dollars this game is definitely worth it, and buying it will certainly bring in a lot of fun.

												Bad Company 2 devoured much of my time on the Playstation 3 when I was in high school. While that community has become extinct, I rejoice at the discovery of a pretty dedicated community here on Steam. My skill has definitely been enhanced by my introduction to Mouse/Keyboard.Great game, lots of destruction, lots of space to move around in. content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												This is fantastic, after having done a bit of it...I can see why Bf Bc2 is the gold standard for many modern FPS.   It's well built, with balanced gameplay.  A decent unlock system.  There are still plenty of active servers (although only a couple in the DLC)  I have 2 complaints.  1) you can't go prone.  That's personal preference, and now that I'm used to it, I can get along without it.  But in my opinion that's something every tactical FPS should include.   2)There is one glitch that I've observed worth mentioning.  With the sighting system on the guns, whether it be iron sights or a scope, there is a glitch where you'll zoom in and it'll suddenly zoom you back out part of the way, you'll stay scoped...but to give an example- --  You'll be using a 4x scope, and suddenly be looking at it from 2x instead of 4x.  That can be quite annoying.The Graphics: 8/10  For something as old as this is, the graphics are quite fantistic.  Explosions look amazing, and they've done a fantastic job with destructable envoirnments, as well as smoke/dust/wind.Multiplayer: 10/10  This is very much a gold standard for multiplayer FPSCampaign:6/10  About average for a modern FPS.Ranking system: 10/10  They've done a good job with unlocks, it's not incredibly unbalanced for beginners, as they still get weapons worth using.Overall: 9/10  I'd very much recommend getting this, if only for the multiplayer experience.

Posted: February 10, 2016
												I rank this up there with COD4 as probably my favorite modern shooter. The buildings are destructible and can collapse and kill players. The maps are laid out perfectly for the game modes. Attack points are all in just the right place.The class system is simple, yet robust. Nothing like newer Battlefields, with their litany of weapons and attachments. No killstreaks or OP weapons. Everyone feels on relatively equal ground, with their gun being their most useful means of attack. If you enjoy FPS for GUNPLAY, then this game is for you.Older game, so it's cheap, but there are still plenty of servers. Can't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												I was going to write a jokeful review because I ended up refunding this game, but I might as well give a real one because why not. In my opinion, the graphics in this game is on par with the newest titles in the series. The buildings look great, the trees and landscapes look amazing, and the water looks real. The gun flashes are perfect and the physics are perfect aside from a few execptions.Audio wise, and again in my opinion, this game is the best in the series and based on the "progression" shown by the devs in BF3 and BF4, this game may have the best audio for many titles to come. I don't really know how to describe why it's so great, it just sounds more realistic to me.As for how active the game is at this date, there were a few active servers, most of them having people in a que to get in. I didn't check for the core servers, but what I said is true for the hardcore servers. The reason I refunded this game is in this area. I researched this game a lot online before buying it, and it seemed like there weren't too many hackers in the game. Maybe I just had bad luck but I came across quite a few in the first hour of playing. I decided not to test my luck any further since the cut off for the refund is 2 hours of play time. I definetly reccommend this game to anyone who loves Battlefield, especially those who don't have the greatest computers, as it is not very strenuous to run this game. This is by far my favorite in the series, but I just dont want to have to deal with the hackers in this game when for the same price I can get BF4.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is hands down the best Battlefield DICE has released. This was the introduction into the Battlefield series for me. Once I played this rendition of Battlefield, I was instantly hooked. BF3, and BF4 are both amazing shooters in their own right, don't get me wrong, however, in my opinion, DICE has yet to match the amazingness that is Bad Company 2. When the Vietnam DLC was realeased for BC2 the game became even more amazing than it already was. How that is even possible, I don't even know. My best memories of a shooter game will definitely involve BC2 Vietnam and the original version of BC2 as well. Vietnam was amazing because of the awesome setting of the DLC (Duh) but also because of the mood the DLC gave off, it seemed just all pure fun and didn't take itself too seriously. One example of that is the music playing when you launch the DLC some awesome classical rock music including, my favorite classical band Creedence Clearwater Revival. Overall I would definitely give this game a 10/10 for an awesome campaign, and just a pure fun multiplayer. I believe whenever DICE decides to make a sequel to BC2 they must do so with care. And remember, to not have the game take itself too seriously and of course, destuction, because what would a Battlfield game be without destruction? Oh, and bringing back Vietnam in the next rendition would be nice too, along with the awesome music! :P

Posted: November 26, 2015
												I enjoyed this game a lot. There are 2 major down sides to this game and the rest is basically great. The biggest issue for me would be the lack of online players. It has been 5 years since the game has launched so the loss of the community is no suprize, but it's still a con. Another one would be it's optimization. From what I have noticed is my game gets a constant 10fps on minimum graphics with a GTX 750ti, now this is the first 20 minutes after starting the game up. After this point the game gets 60fps fine on max graphics. I don't know why this happens, but it does. Of course now for the pros right. Well I find it hard to specify specific parts of the game that make it as good as it is. The driving and shooting fell good with little to no aim assist. The campaign is pretty well put together and has some weird glitches starting and finishing a cutscene, but nothing gamebreaking. The actual campaing has 2 main areas a snow desert and a jungle which both look very well for 2010. The Jungle reminds me of Halo 3 the mission sierra 117 persoanlly. The button layout isn't ideal at start, but you can configure that so who cares. I do reccomend playing with atleast 1 friend because then you can play on a serrver alone with your friend/friends. This can be a lot of fun and will allow you to do fun glitches or just d**king around. I reccomend this game if you enjoy the battlefield series, have a group of friends that will play with you, and for nistolgia of course.

content:
Posted: April 15
												Occasionally I fall back on BFBC2 to play the great campaign. Here's my review. I don't write a lot, and there's not much chance this will reach the front, but to those who read this:  It's worth the 20$ (standalone price).   Battlefield Bad Company 2 is the sequel to the original. I have not played the original, but from the campaign and the witty characters, I can tell the company has a strong bond (at least in this game). Battlefield Bad Company 2 has a great storyline to it, and develops the story line very interesting. It also balances out storyline with gameplay - meaning that you won't have 30-minute-long story cuts (exaggerations), but instead be able to be part of the action. For instance - you're sneaking on an enemy and your team intends on going about the job in a sneaky way. You have only your trust combat knife, and there's 1 enemy at the watchtower you need to take out to get the job clean. The story doesn't do it for you; you have to creep up (crouch) and sneakily assassinate him. After that, the story may resume.  The story, again, is very detailed and nicely planned. It is not something someone made up within a day - it is something made up within weeks, or even months.  The only downside is that the campaign is really short. You can finish it within a couple hours, at most a day or two. Still, it's worth it.  Since this is 20$ and it is 7 year of age (up to this review), the game has not been updated, but has been kept alive. There are about 20 or so multiplayer servers hosted in a multitude of countries that keep the multiplayer section still running, for when you finish that really quick campaign.   The game's way of playing is unlike anything else. It's like a regular schooter, but you will see that within the multiplayer, and a little bit of singleplayer, you will have to use other things. For example, there are 4 classes; Assault, Medic, Recon, and Engineer ( ***please note that in the single player you can change up primariers and secondaries and you do not have classes***). The Assault is a basic class; usual primary with an auto/burstfire rifle and a pocket pistol. The Recon is a somewhat complex class; you have a motion sensor ball that when thrown will recieve radio signals. If you're on the US side, and you hear english, there are teammates nearby. If you're on the US side, and you hear russian, there are enemies by [and you need to start poppin' some ruskis, no hate to my russians] and vice-versa. The Recon also has about 5 C4's. You can lay down C4 and with a right-click, they detonate. C4's are highlighted with detailed circles on your mini-map and while visible. What's fun is that you can attach C4's onto your car (in MP) and drive them into enemy tanks or just enemy territory, get out, and set off the C4's, making funny kills. Recon comes with a sniper rifle and pistol. The Medic class usually comes with a defibrillator and you can resurrect teammates. I have seen this, but in old servers - it may be removed in newer ones. Medic has a PKM usually (or any LMG) and, of course, a pistol. The Engineer is my favorite class. Usually, this class comes with a silenced machine-pistol (or SMG), and a regular pistol. The Engineer, in MP, has a rocket launcher (usually just the russian RPG), which will prove to be very helpful when blowing up enemy tanks and/or jeeps / ATVs.  The engineer class also comes with a power-drill that can heal vehicles, any vehicle (probably don't want to do it on your enemy's vehicle though) and can also kill. Yes, you can kill with a power drill, and yes, it's very funny.   In the end, this game is really amazing, even after years of being on the Steam shop. Its campaign may be short, but Multiplayer will definitely suit your needs. Multiplayer is also the most fun, depending on how you are.  In short, for $20 and with an age of 5+ years (at the time of this review 7 years), Battlefield: Bad Company 2 serves as a great game overall regardless of its short campaign, which it makes up for again with the multiplayer. I sincerely recommend this game for nostalgia, battlefield playstyle, and fun times with an FPS game. Consider the $20 worth it.

Posted: June 8, 2015
												I was going to write a jokeful review because I ended up refunding this game, but I might as well give a real one because why not. In my opinion, the graphics in this game is on par with the newest titles in the series. The buildings look great, the trees and landscapes look amazing, and the water looks real. The gun flashes are perfect and the physics are perfect aside from a few execptions.Audio wise, and again in my opinion, this game is the best in the series and based on the "progression" shown by the devs in BF3 and BF4, this game may have the best audio for many titles to come. I don't really know how to describe why it's so great, it just sounds more realistic to me.As for how active the game is at this date, there were a few active servers, most of them having people in a que to get in. I didn't check for the core servers, but what I said is true for the hardcore servers. The reason I refunded this game is in this area. I researched this game a lot online before buying it, and it seemed like there weren't too many hackers in the game. Maybe I just had bad luck but I came across quite a few in the first hour of playing. I decided not to test my luck any further since the cut off for the refund is 2 hours of play time. I definetly reccommend this game to anyone who loves Battlefield, especially those who don't have the greatest computers, as it is not very strenuous to run this game. This is by far my favorite in the series, but I just dont want to have to deal with the hackers in this game when for the same price I can get BF4.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												I truly belive this game can give you PTSD, no joke.Why? Ill explainStory: I honestly dont give a ♥♥♥♥, but, i enjoy it because while it does follow your FPS stereotypes of (insert country/terrorist) are invading america and its up to you and (insert a cast of burly americans and one minorty because were not racist) to stop. Yet the game is light hearted and self aware threw out and if it was an action movie it would be alright.Gameplay: The story missions are somewhat linear and some of the things the game expects you to do is bull♥♥♥♥♥♥ But there alright. YET, the multiplayer is where it shines. Your given a large map with tons of vehicles and buildings and you shoot it up. And all the classes have a use, with large maps snipers can pick off pepole in enemy bases one by one without the other team noticeing. The assault is the one that goes in at close range to take enemys on. Engineres(my favorite) can both repair and destroy vehicles, which is extremly usefull on bigger maps. And medics can deal damage and heal teamates. Plus you can be put in a squad to take on enemys all at once. Also theres bullet drop, which i honestly dont like on most classes but it makes snipeing satisfying.But the one selling point of the game is how all the buildings are destroyable. You are not safe ever in this game... EVER. You die quickly and there are tanks, RPGS, helecpoters, everything that can blow you up. And if your house takes a bad enough beatings it completly colapses killing you. This makes the game super tense AND I LOVE IT!Presntation: Notice how i didnt put GRAPHICS. Because while the game looks good, ive still seen better. But where the game truly makes belive you can get PTSD is the sound desighn. This game has the best sound desighn in any game ive ever played. When a bomb blows up next to you, its LOUD, and makes your characters ears ring or muffles the noises. You can hear bullets miles away or when they just miss your head. Ive honsetly jumped from the sound of a snipers bullet wizzing by my head. And when a building is about to collapes, you hear the sound of metal bending, then the entire house falling and its scary. There is rarley a quiet moment in this game and it is stressfull. AND I LOVE IT!Get this game. Its great.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												NOTE: I played so much more of this game before I found it on Steam.What a wondrous creation. Where to begin? I think this game became so much more than it meant to be, which is great, but alas time goes on, and so many people have moved on to bigger and badder titles. However, just to be clear, as of my writing, this game -->STILL HAS A MULTIPLAYER PRESENCE<-- In fact, it was a bit bigger than I expected, with multiple servers still available to play on. Vietnam is a bit worse off though...Anyways, moving along to the good stuff.Bad Co. 2 had a pretty nice engine and look. Frostbite 2 was great, and the destructibility of environment items was amazing at the time, it felt rather new and exciting. The attention to detail was fantastic as well, the scenes typically felt as if they were alive instead of some dull backdrop to your gunplay. The maps, both in SP and MP, looked rather stunning. In multiplayer, the levolution was creative, and often times very exciting to experience.Oh, gunplay! Did it feel joyous? Well there were some flaws, as per usual, but BC2 certainly made up for those. It was nice, at least. There were (and still are) several occasions upon which I would 'trade' lives with an opponent. That's alright though. Weapons at least fire bullets. It was a ton of fun to have to deal with bullet drop, and watch people play terribly because they came from a hitscan game. There was a nice selection of weapons to choose from in each class, and several weapons that were usable in all kits! Classes felt great in multiplayer if you ask me. Giving LMGs and medic items to a support class felt ingenious, whilst having engineers stealth via suppressed weapons and blow things up, assault characters drop ammo kits and provide grenade launcher support (with different types of rounds), and recon players call in mortar strikes, throw radar mines, and... snipe. It felt a little more balanced and well rounded, albeit the fact that the occasional wall of recon players seemed indestructible.Single player had it's side of followers as well, and for good reason. The story seemed well cared for, and it was structured well. There was enough variety in the levels and combat experience in each mission, that I didn't feel like I was playing one never-ending unchanging campaign. I also got really attached to the characters, as I'm sure many people did. Each personality was fleshed out, detailed, and lovable. It was all of the squad members put together, with a kickass story, and a variety of gameplay options that made this the game we still love 6 years laterThis is all I've got on this one for now, I've left out a ton that others loved about the game, but add to it! You know what you loved about BC2!Check out the beefier review: http://wp.me/p73yYy-4c

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Awesome game. Very fun and multiplayer is very much alive after so many years. It is an old game and a cheap one. Gameplay is very good and graphics are nice also. I strongly recommend this game to everyone. For those who cant find a multiplayer game: Start the game, click Multiplayer and then choose Server Browser, log in to your EA account and create a soldier then choose him. Now on ALL SERVERS tab in the right choose a game mode (I usually play on CONQUEST it is more fun than others) or leave it at All game modes and click search. DO NOT narrow the search down anymore leave it at all maps and at all regions for a start and dont tick any boxes also. then a list of servers will appear. Now at this list click twice on a tab called PLAYERS this will filter the list by the number of players playing on servers. Choose a server and have fun. There are hardcore servers too and you probably dont want to play there in the beginning, but later on they are very fun also. There is always a good amount of players online (24/7). Be aware that some servers have in descriptions a higher exp amount where you will level up your soldiers rank and equipment very fast. If you like easy life you can play there, but I prefer to work my way up myself and play on low exp servers and learn every new weapon as I play. It is also much more rewarding like that. From server list you can also put servers to favorite list so you dont have to search every time for a fun server. There is less players in Vietnam DLC which is a shame, but the main game will offer a lot of fun in multiplayer at any point of a day. Campagin is very interesting too. Good story. And if you buy the game you wont have to purchase anything in the game itself. It is probably because there isnt anyhing to purchase :)

content:
Posted: April 15
												Occasionally I fall back on BFBC2 to play the great campaign. Here's my review. I don't write a lot, and there's not much chance this will reach the front, but to those who read this:  It's worth the 20$ (standalone price).   Battlefield Bad Company 2 is the sequel to the original. I have not played the original, but from the campaign and the witty characters, I can tell the company has a strong bond (at least in this game). Battlefield Bad Company 2 has a great storyline to it, and develops the story line very interesting. It also balances out storyline with gameplay - meaning that you won't have 30-minute-long story cuts (exaggerations), but instead be able to be part of the action. For instance - you're sneaking on an enemy and your team intends on going about the job in a sneaky way. You have only your trust combat knife, and there's 1 enemy at the watchtower you need to take out to get the job clean. The story doesn't do it for you; you have to creep up (crouch) and sneakily assassinate him. After that, the story may resume.  The story, again, is very detailed and nicely planned. It is not something someone made up within a day - it is something made up within weeks, or even months.  The only downside is that the campaign is really short. You can finish it within a couple hours, at most a day or two. Still, it's worth it.  Since this is 20$ and it is 7 year of age (up to this review), the game has not been updated, but has been kept alive. There are about 20 or so multiplayer servers hosted in a multitude of countries that keep the multiplayer section still running, for when you finish that really quick campaign.   The game's way of playing is unlike anything else. It's like a regular schooter, but you will see that within the multiplayer, and a little bit of singleplayer, you will have to use other things. For example, there are 4 classes; Assault, Medic, Recon, and Engineer ( ***please note that in the single player you can change up primariers and secondaries and you do not have classes***). The Assault is a basic class; usual primary with an auto/burstfire rifle and a pocket pistol. The Recon is a somewhat complex class; you have a motion sensor ball that when thrown will recieve radio signals. If you're on the US side, and you hear english, there are teammates nearby. If you're on the US side, and you hear russian, there are enemies by [and you need to start poppin' some ruskis, no hate to my russians] and vice-versa. The Recon also has about 5 C4's. You can lay down C4 and with a right-click, they detonate. C4's are highlighted with detailed circles on your mini-map and while visible. What's fun is that you can attach C4's onto your car (in MP) and drive them into enemy tanks or just enemy territory, get out, and set off the C4's, making funny kills. Recon comes with a sniper rifle and pistol. The Medic class usually comes with a defibrillator and you can resurrect teammates. I have seen this, but in old servers - it may be removed in newer ones. Medic has a PKM usually (or any LMG) and, of course, a pistol. The Engineer is my favorite class. Usually, this class comes with a silenced machine-pistol (or SMG), and a regular pistol. The Engineer, in MP, has a rocket launcher (usually just the russian RPG), which will prove to be very helpful when blowing up enemy tanks and/or jeeps / ATVs.  The engineer class also comes with a power-drill that can heal vehicles, any vehicle (probably don't want to do it on your enemy's vehicle though) and can also kill. Yes, you can kill with a power drill, and yes, it's very funny.   In the end, this game is really amazing, even after years of being on the Steam shop. Its campaign may be short, but Multiplayer will definitely suit your needs. Multiplayer is also the most fun, depending on how you are.  In short, for $20 and with an age of 5+ years (at the time of this review 7 years), Battlefield: Bad Company 2 serves as a great game overall regardless of its short campaign, which it makes up for again with the multiplayer. I sincerely recommend this game for nostalgia, battlefield playstyle, and fun times with an FPS game. Consider the $20 worth it.

												I enjoyed this game a lot. There are 2 major down sides to this game and the rest is basically great. The biggest issue for me would be the lack of online players. It has been 5 years since the game has launched so the loss of the community is no suprize, but it's still a con. Another one would be it's optimization. From what I have noticed is my game gets a constant 10fps on minimum graphics with a GTX 750ti, now this is the first 20 minutes after starting the game up. After this point the game gets 60fps fine on max graphics. I don't know why this happens, but it does. Of course now for the pros right. Well I find it hard to specify specific parts of the game that make it as good as it is. The driving and shooting fell good with little to no aim assist. The campaign is pretty well put together and has some weird glitches starting and finishing a cutscene, but nothing gamebreaking. The actual campaing has 2 main areas a snow desert and a jungle which both look very well for 2010. The Jungle reminds me of Halo 3 the mission sierra 117 persoanlly. The button layout isn't ideal at start, but you can configure that so who cares. I do reccomend playing with atleast 1 friend because then you can play on a serrver alone with your friend/friends. This can be a lot of fun and will allow you to do fun glitches or just d**king around. I reccomend this game if you enjoy the battlefield series, have a group of friends that will play with you, and for nistolgia of course.

												Let me tell you a story. A story of a certain soldier, named Tom.  He was very unexperienced, and didn't really know what he was doing. He deployed with his squad, who all got orders to rush straight into a tank. Tom didn't rush, however. Tom was clever. He quickly fell to the ground and laid there. The tank, after killing his whole squad, drove past Tom and did not notice him. At that point, Tom was in the middle of a field, surrounded by enemies and, if he made one wrong move, would be spotted and shot down by the enemy snipers. He thought "why didn't I rush? I bet that tank was one rocket away from exploding, and yet, I just didn't attack it".  Tom laid there, waiting for the innevitable. Finaly, after gaining the courage, he stood up, and started running to the closest cover possible. Everything turned blurry, as he was being suppressed by sniper fire. "This is it" he said to himself while running, "I'm not fast enough". A bullet hit Tom straight in the chest. Luckily, it didn't kill him, but he felt as if he was one hit from a pistol away from dying. As he counted the time between the shots, suddenly, they stopped. After getting into cover near a rock, Tom met a friendly squad consisting of a Medic and a Sniper. After shouting "I need a medic!" about 50 times, the friendly Medic dropped Tom a kit, and, within 10 seconds Tom felt as if he had just deployed. The sniper yelled "Move up!" and the medic took out a huge assault rifle. Tom prepared to Move Up aswell. The sniper took out his pistol and made a dash for a nearby jeep. The medic started running behind him. Tom stood up aswell, but he was far behind the Squad. Suddenly, as the jeep was about to ride off, it started Honking like crazy. It didn't drive. It could've driven. It was in a dangerous field, but, the driver still waited for Tom to get in. He ran as fast as he could, shouting "Thanks!" atleast three times.>Tank from before killed them.10/10 would meet amazing people for 3 minutes and then never meet them again.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Possibly the greatest shooter of its time.BFBC2 was and still is an excellent shooter. The game is built on the classic and well done squad based shooter. There are 4 different classes, Assault, Engineer, Medic and Recon. Each class has it's own specific weaponry and perks which it can use to alter the way the class plays. For example, do you want to be a long range support sniper? Choose a high calibre rifle and mortat strike. Want to play close recon? Choose an SMG or a sniper with a red dot scope, tracking orbs and something like C4. This is viable for all classes. One thing that this game is excellent is, is weapon balance. Yes there are still standout choices, but every gun has a niche that it can sit in nicely. I mainly play Medic, and loved playing the Spas12 with long range SS shells, and magnum ammo. Medics can also easily play with the non-class specific SMGs or rifles, or play as a heavy support class with LMGs, all of which are equally balanced depending on how you want to play; up close with the M60, or further back with a lower recoil like MG9 for example. The whole shooter is balanced excellently. The vehicles are somewhat difficult to counter at times, but this is normally because they are played by good pilots or drivers. An Apache chopper with a skilled gunner will cause havoc, unless your team can club together, tag the chopper and RPG it; or maybe a sniper can take it down. The whole game is based on team co-operation; in stark contrast to dumb shooters like CoD, which rely on pounding as many kills from spawn trapping and kill streaks. These don't exist in BFBC2, and the game is hugely more enjoyable from it. The game is still active even with the release of BF3 and BF4, and that is because the game is fun, balanced and enjoyable, and Hardcore is a must.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2011
												I've been enjoyed BF games since Desert Combat in 2003, and BC2 stands tall as one of the best in the series.  The game finally has a single player game that isn't insultingly bad, but BF is best as a multiplayer team based objective game.  The singleplayer is interesting and tells a quixotic story of four soldiers on a mission to recover something-or-other and has them globetrotting to visually exciting environments. It's like Call of Duty but not so ham-fisted with the rhetoric; you'll still wince though.  Multiplayer SHINES LIKE A DIAMOND.  Map variety is pleasing, and the lethality of the weapons is very satisfying and balanced. Teamplay support is VERY enforced enabling a strong sense of contributing to the whole. You WANT to help your team. Respawning is handled smartly, and unlocks + upgrades are very worthwhile. Every class soldier is fun and a unique style that is compelling to play over and over again with numerous ways to customize and finesse your approach.  100% worthy.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												I did my research before purchasing this game, and it definitely paid off. The campaign is enjoyable, but unfortunately, not too memorable - however, the cons end there. Of course, this game is most well-known for it's astounding multiplayer experience - many say the best in the Battlefield franchise - and it definitely lives up to, even surpasses, expectations. It is incredibly thrilling and intense - I often find myself leaning closer to the screen to make out an enemy sniper in the distance, or stopping and turning my character side to side in order to pinpoint the direction of footsteps or gunfire. There is a large enough range of firearms to keep a player interested for awhile, and plenty of perks and attachments to mix and match. The map and weapon design, and graphic style in general are beautiful, even on the lowest settings, and each game mode provides new tactics and exciting motives for both teams. Finally, no other videogame, that I've encountered at least, has purely awesome moments quite like this one. Perhaps you'll parachute over an enemy tank, chuck some C-4 down and get the vehicle kill, then mow down an entire squad Rambo-style with your M249 SAW LMG and top it off by capturing the point. Or maybe you prefer a stealthier approach - spotting an enemy on the other side of the map zooming around in an ATV, scoping in with your M-95 sniper rifle, calculating the bullet-drop and lead distance correctly and nailing the headshot on the moving target. Then the building you're hiding in takes a tank shell and begins to collapse, so you leap out of the falling structure, knife another unsuspecting soldier down below, and detonate the final M-COM to win your team the game. The possibilities are virtually endless, and each one is more epic than the last.I could go on, but I don't want to spoil anything else. This game is absolutely worth the price it asks for, and I guarantee it will have you playing for hours on end.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2011
												Although PC users where shunned from the first Battlefield: Bad Company (BF: BC), BF: BC2 more than makes up from this oversight and doesn't require you to have played the original. The singleplayer of BF: BC2 is short, but fun with an unusual set of characters that will leave you somewhat satisfied. However, the multiplayer aspect of the game is where BF: BC2 shines brighter than any other first-person shooter (FPS) to date. Using the Frostbite engine, BF: BC2 offers destructible environments and class-based modern warfare that offers 4 total classes (Assault, Engineer, Medic and Recon). The multiplayer is a blast and well worth the money for FPS enthusiasts.The special acquisition (SPECACT) kit upgrade for Battlefield: Bad Company 2 (BF: BC2) holds a few advantages for players who are multiplayer fanatics. The SPECACT essentially doubles your classes by allowing you to choose either the default skins or the SPECACT skins that are denoted by their SA tags (e.g. Assault, Assault SA, Engineer, Engineer SA, etc). It also gives you access to a few new weapon choices that are only camouflaged editions of select default weapons such as the M95 SA, the UMP 45 SA, etc. These additions can be used to earn more kill stars for more points. It should be noted that purchasing this DLC kit will give you a CD-Key that you must redeem via BF: BC2's in-game menu while logged into your EA account.The Vietnam expansion is a multiplayer addition for Battlefield: Bad Company 2. The game's mechanics play the same, but with more maps and weapons built around the Frostbite engine. The multiplayer for Battlefield: Bad Company 2 has always been the core component for the game and the Vietnam expansion provides a worthwhile investment for more action-packed fun for Battlefield fans. It should be noted that the maps are set in a jungle environment that limits destruction 2.0.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Bad Company 2 finds a nice medium between the communication-reliant tacticality of Battlefield 2 and the arcadey run-n-gun of more conventional arena shooters. It rewards teamwork, but it's just as fun to hop in a server solo and find your own place in the warzone. It has many unlockable weapons that allow for a variety of gameplay methods, and the maps span the range from close-quarters urban areas to vast plains where vehicles are all but mandatory. Speaking of which, infantry has more of a focus in this game so they're not just fodder for the few players that nab a plane or tanks- a change from previous titles in the franchise's history. Though the physics, collision, hit detection, and netcode can be buggy occasionally, the rest of the time makes up for it with exciting, tense, fulfilling action.Being such an old game, however, the amount of servers is dwindling, but you can still find matches. You just can't be as picky with server options.

												Battlefield Bad Company 2 is quite possibly my favorite battlefield game that is still operational (RIP BF2 and BF2142). At its core it is a class based multiplayer shooter, but it also has a lovable singleplayer cast. I will try to outline my favorite parts of this game and hopefully y'all will find this helpful!Technical StuffGetting this game to run well was a pain at first because the default configuration files are horrid.  Thanks to a few Steam guides though, it is easy to troubleshoot your issues and fix them promptly. Something is seriously wrong with the DX11 renderer but once I switched it to DX9, my frame rate sat comfortably in the 100's with no noticeable stuttering. To add to this, the visuals between DX11 and DX9 are nigh-identical so you won't be missing out on any of the graphical goodness. The game's visuals hold up beautifully for a 6 year old game. The explosions will give you wargasms; the sound system of this game is unmatched by other Battlefield titles. There is nothing like hearing your assault rifle behave differently when you are firing inside confined spaces and outside of structures. All in all a fantastic visual and audio experience once you get the renderer to behave.Singleplayer (Whats that?)Compared to the last bad company title, the BFBC2 campaign takes itself a bit more seriously, but it still manages to pull off some of the humorous moments that the first game was known for. Haggard is as absurdly Redneck as they come and Sweetwater still talks faster than the RPM of a boat propeller. Sarge has postponed his retirement once again to lead our band of misfits through a crazy explosion filled adventure. Battlefield games are not known for their single player campaigns, but I suggest that you play a few missions and see if you like the flavor. You might enjoy it as much as I did.MultiplayerTo find servers on the server browser, you must hit the "Search" button to populate the server listBFBC2 Multiplayer is alive and well to this day which is quite a feat for a 6 year old game. Many servers are populated throughout the day which means you will be able to get the Bad Company experience any time you so desire. It is worth noting that all Map Pack DLC is included with the PC version of the game; absolutely glorious and I wish DICE still continued this practice. The multiplayer is class based. You can chose from the rifle wielding Assault, the SMG toting Engineer, the LMG lugging Medic, and the Sniper Rifle carrying Recon. The Recon kit is not solely a sniper! Use your gadgets to help your team reconnoiter an area and stop trying to get your MLG pro-scope montages. This isn't the game for that. Each class has a variety of gadgets designed to support the team and mastering the use of these gadgets is very rewarding!SummaryClass based multiplayerGuns have beefy sounds, it doesn't feel like you are playing with water squirters!No proliferation of useless unlocks. The game has around 7-8 different primary weapons per class, each feels different and has a different role. Once you unlock a weapon optic you get it for ALL of your weapons of that class. There aren't 50 types of "elite holographic heartbeat sensing aimbot gunsights" in this gameOptics are not needed to use your weapons effectively! Most of the time you best off with iron sights and using your ability slot for something more helpful.You can stick a dang red dot on a .50 caliber bolt action rifle! How isn't that awesome?!Gunplay feels solid. Be sure to tap-fire at longer ranges!Tanks feel like Tanks! You aren't driving a soggy cardboard box and you feel like a total badass if you use it properly!Maps feel like they were designed for each specific game mode. Rush plays like Rush and Conquest plays like Conquest. You will not feel that you are playing a map for a different game modeNo stupid knifing animations. No counter-knifing either!If you can see it, you can blow it up! Nearly every building can be brought down with the "careful" removal of a few walls (Blow that crap up with explosives and watch the collapse crush your enemies!) New battlefield games have lost this destructibility, but Bad Company does it right! The battlefield will feel like a warzone as the battle drags on; what once was a quaint village transforms to a pile of flaming rubble while troops fight over the scraps!Do I recommend this game? Absolutely! I played this game endlessly on console until I made the switch to PC. This game is great fun for newcomers to the series and long-time veterans like myself!

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												I'd recommend this game, but it has some major problems.1. WAY WAY too much smoke and dust clouds. Even a short spray of bullets will cause a cloud of dust that takes awhile to disappear, even when you shot at something like a window frame, wall corner, door frame, etc.2. The vehicles suck, for the most part.3. No option for team deathmatch, only Squad Deathmatch. (4 teams of 4 against each other)4. No option for free for all deathmatch.5. Every Squad Deathmatch map has one tank that continues to spawn. It's annoying and wasn't a good choice of vehicle for Squad Deathmatch. Humvees or 4-wheelers would have worked better. Maybe a few boats on the maps that have water. 6. Only sniper rifles can be equipped with a sniper scope.7. Heli control(s) suck, and minigun control (that the heli's are equipped with) also suck.  8. Way too few maps for Squad Deathmatch option, and the maps for the other gametypes are often large with not enough buildings/cover/good landscape for a battle. Why not just spawn us all in an open field?9. Extreme lack of good urban environment maps.10. This is one of the worst things about the game. Accuracy is ridiculously crappy when you aren't looking through your sights/optics. You can fire at a stationary guy 20 feet away and maybe get 3-6 out of 30 of your shots to actually hit him. If you need to be looking down your sights to get more than 1/10-1/5 accuracy from 20 feet away, then you probably shouldn't be anywhere near a battlefield. In real life if I was shooting from that distance, every one of the those shots would have met their target. Seeming as how most of the assault rifles used by assault class are chambered in 5.56mm, they should by little to no issue with recoil. The game's designers, however, thought that it best to give rifles chambered in 5.56mm the accuracy and recoil of an automatic shotgun being fired by a small child with Muscular Dystrophy.11. This one isn't as big of a deal to me, but there's no option to go prone.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Very brief mention - this is a REVIEW. I hope people get the common ♥♥♥♥ing sense to write REVIEWS on these pages instead of little stories or cooking recipes. It and anybody who does that are completely pathetic.Now, moving on...I was a veteran of this game on the Xbox 360 - when I say veteran, I mean I recognize the sounds of each gun being shot from afar, even the suppressed weapons. I got lots of enjoyment out of it, and I couldn't help but "upgrade" to the PC version. I upgraded for several reasons:1) I felt that more people played the PC version, since that's the target console of the series.2) I was sure that the graphics would be improved on the PC.3) I would be able to browse servers instead of just doing a mandatory quick match on the 360.Within about half an hour I got all three of those points addressed.1) There are FAR more people on the PC version as opposed to the Xbox 360. There aren't tons of full servers, but there are still a rather stunning number of people with taste in terms of Battlefield games.2) The graphics. Holy CRAP. 60 fps without tweaking a single setting. Overwhelming lighting effects. Much larger and more detailed levels.3) Server browsing is just as useful as I suspected it would be. There is a glitch, however, where when you start up the game and go under server browsing, there's an empty list - don't fret; the fix is to simply press "Search", and they all load in.Now, in terms of gameplay; it's perfectly balanced and hectic gameplay that rewards players of all playstyles, both infantry and vehicular. It stays basic without falling to the crap that Battlefield 3 and Battlefield 4 brought to the table; there's none of that "lengthy reload on an empty magazine" BS; there's no suppression; you don't wake up from a nap after getting revived, only to get shot again; there's no vehicle healing or crippling; no crazy weapon attachments...None of that crap is present here. If you want more of that, don't buy this game.The singleplayer took a shot to the head in comparison to its predecessor (an Xbox 360/PS3 exclusive; I wish it were on the PC, too :,C), in the regard to how boring it was, and how fast you'll shoot through it. There's a video on YouTube (it should still be up) of somebody beating the campaign in just slightly over THREE HOURS. Enemies die in one or two shots, which renders all challenge moot, everything is scripted and hideously linear, and there's little to no point playing it. The four main characters just become dreadfully unlikable in the campaign; again, in stark opposition to the first game. With the sole exception of Battlefield: Bad Company (1), all BF games' strengths are in their multiplayer.So do I recommend this game? YES. ABSOLUTELY. It was phenomonal on the Xbox 360, and it's equally as nice on the PC. It has better ease-of-access when it comes to finding matches, better graphics, and is just completely mindblowing.And, of course, it has a massive Vietnam War expansion/conversion...

content:
Posted: March 19
												Hands down the best Battlefield game ever made. The movement control is a little off, but nothing you don't get used to in 10 minutes. The destruction, while not as high in fidelity as later titles, is more fun and actually contributes to gameplay. You won't be hiding behind that cover for long, buddy. (Those who complain about leveled maps are playing too high ticket servers.)The sniping is the best it's ever been. Getting a headshot from thousands of meters away is so rewarding and doesn't just feel like total luck when you do it. A good sniper is a force to be reckoned with and you'll have to work with your team to take them out. None of this permanent scope glare nonsense that BF3-1 has. Every map is memorable and designed with alot of care. Every match feels different.The weapon variety is some of the best in any FPS game. Though BC2 doesn't have the largest selection, every gun is viable and can be mastered if you put in the effort. There is no lock on missiles, which makes flying helicopters a blast. (They may be a little overpowered, but they are fun as hell when you are not on the recieving end.)These seemingly small things make the game infinitely more playable and fun then newer BFs. In my opinion nothing DICE has made since has came close.  BF3, 4 and 1 aren't even in the same league. It's sad that we may never see a BF as good as this one.Why are you even reading reviews? Buy it.

												Very brief mention - this is a REVIEW. I hope people get the common ♥♥♥♥ing sense to write REVIEWS on these pages instead of little stories or cooking recipes. It and anybody who does that are completely pathetic.Now, moving on...I was a veteran of this game on the Xbox 360 - when I say veteran, I mean I recognize the sounds of each gun being shot from afar, even the suppressed weapons. I got lots of enjoyment out of it, and I couldn't help but "upgrade" to the PC version. I upgraded for several reasons:1) I felt that more people played the PC version, since that's the target console of the series.2) I was sure that the graphics would be improved on the PC.3) I would be able to browse servers instead of just doing a mandatory quick match on the 360.Within about half an hour I got all three of those points addressed.1) There are FAR more people on the PC version as opposed to the Xbox 360. There aren't tons of full servers, but there are still a rather stunning number of people with taste in terms of Battlefield games.2) The graphics. Holy CRAP. 60 fps without tweaking a single setting. Overwhelming lighting effects. Much larger and more detailed levels.3) Server browsing is just as useful as I suspected it would be. There is a glitch, however, where when you start up the game and go under server browsing, there's an empty list - don't fret; the fix is to simply press "Search", and they all load in.Now, in terms of gameplay; it's perfectly balanced and hectic gameplay that rewards players of all playstyles, both infantry and vehicular. It stays basic without falling to the crap that Battlefield 3 and Battlefield 4 brought to the table; there's none of that "lengthy reload on an empty magazine" BS; there's no suppression; you don't wake up from a nap after getting revived, only to get shot again; there's no vehicle healing or crippling; no crazy weapon attachments...None of that crap is present here. If you want more of that, don't buy this game.The singleplayer took a shot to the head in comparison to its predecessor (an Xbox 360/PS3 exclusive; I wish it were on the PC, too :,C), in the regard to how boring it was, and how fast you'll shoot through it. There's a video on YouTube (it should still be up) of somebody beating the campaign in just slightly over THREE HOURS. Enemies die in one or two shots, which renders all challenge moot, everything is scripted and hideously linear, and there's little to no point playing it. The four main characters just become dreadfully unlikable in the campaign; again, in stark opposition to the first game. With the sole exception of Battlefield: Bad Company (1), all BF games' strengths are in their multiplayer.So do I recommend this game? YES. ABSOLUTELY. It was phenomonal on the Xbox 360, and it's equally as nice on the PC. It has better ease-of-access when it comes to finding matches, better graphics, and is just completely mindblowing.And, of course, it has a massive Vietnam War expansion/conversion...

Posted: April 20, 2015
												Graphics	9A beautifully rendered world, extremely satisfying levels of destruction, grand animations, and an easy to understand interface. Battlefield: Bad Company 2 has it all.Gameplay	9At times, it feels like there are some frustrating balance issues. But those are few and far between. Bad Company 2 is a fantastic game to pick up and go to town with. You'll find glee in causing buildings to crumble around you, planting that charge of C4 on a tank and blowing it up, nailing that perfect headshot from across the map. However, where Bad Company 2 really shines is when you log on with some friends and get coordinated. Communicate and work together to outgun, outflank, and outdo the enemy team.Story	4I'll be honest with you. If you are playing Battlefield games for the story, you're going to be really, really disappointed. While there is a storymode here, it honestly isn't worth much of your time except as a glorified tutorial. The characters do give a few good laughs though.Multiplayer	10As mentioned earlier, Bad Company 2 really shines when you play with friends, but even alone you're going to have a blast with this one. Hours and hours of fun and destruction await you, with several different modes of multiplayer available to choose from. Be warned though, if you join up this late in the game you're going to face some very, very good long-time players.Replayability	9You're going to keep coming back to this one. The peak of the Battlefield series so far, it never gets old racing out of a building as it crumbles around you, covering your team on a withdrawal from an overrun area, or being at the front of a charge to capture a point. Don't miss out on one of the most enjoyable Battlefield experiences yet. The only struggle here is that most your friends will probably have moved on to the new battlefields.Overall9.2/10Though not as popular as it once was (due to the new battlefields) Bad Company 2 still stands at the top of the Battlefield mountain. The Frostbite engine really shines in this iteration. Multiplayer is fast-paced, brutal, and spectacularly fun. Don't like those trees? Mow them down with your LMG. Don't like that building? Blow it up. Your team being overrun? Call in an artillery strike and give them some relief. All in all, an absolute must have for any Battlefield fan.

Posted: March 19
												Hands down the best Battlefield game ever made. The movement control is a little off, but nothing you don't get used to in 10 minutes. The destruction, while not as high in fidelity as later titles, is more fun and actually contributes to gameplay. You won't be hiding behind that cover for long, buddy. (Those who complain about leveled maps are playing too high ticket servers.)The sniping is the best it's ever been. Getting a headshot from thousands of meters away is so rewarding and doesn't just feel like total luck when you do it. A good sniper is a force to be reckoned with and you'll have to work with your team to take them out. None of this permanent scope glare nonsense that BF3-1 has. Every map is memorable and designed with alot of care. Every match feels different.The weapon variety is some of the best in any FPS game. Though BC2 doesn't have the largest selection, every gun is viable and can be mastered if you put in the effort. There is no lock on missiles, which makes flying helicopters a blast. (They may be a little overpowered, but they are fun as hell when you are not on the recieving end.)These seemingly small things make the game infinitely more playable and fun then newer BFs. In my opinion nothing DICE has made since has came close.  BF3, 4 and 1 aren't even in the same league. It's sad that we may never see a BF as good as this one.Why are you even reading reviews? Buy it.

content:
Posted: March 19
A great older title that has aged well, but has gone a little senile.Due to the age of the game and EA no longer supporting it, you really only get the Single Player campaign to play unless you made an account when the game was supported. With that said, I'm not sure there'd be much online activity for this game now anyway. This review is for the Single Player campaign only.Despite being a 7 year old game, it has aged gracefully. The visuals are top notch and are still comparable to games released this year. The story is decent, but short. You get 5 hours of solid, unsurprising story. Whimsical characters help populate the experience with some humour, but don’t expect a serious FPS.Age brings about some technical issues with newer systems. Running this on Windows 10, there were frequent technical, but not game-breaking issues. First of all, the physics engine has little freak-outs every now and then. Ragdolls will bounce into the air for no reason and some physics objects do some rather hilarious dance moves.Scripting just doesn’t work sometimes, with funny, but awkward results. In one cutscene, one of the actors failed to load so things were just floating around and reacting to an invisible person. Your AI companions occasionally refuse to advance and will wait for you to do all the work before magically teleporting ahead of you. The funniest thing I found was a bug where a helicopter would have enemies rappel to an area ahead of you, only to have them drop out instead and die. Of a helicopter with six enemies, only one managed to use the rope to rappel down. They should really teach their troops better.I’d say these errors are down to modern systems and older code just not being compatible. In any case, none of it was game-breaking. If you’re looking for a classic, no-frills shooter, then this is still a top game.

content:
Posted: February 15
												Alright, so I know this isn't the newest, or the most hyped Battlefield-game out there, but trust me when I tell you, it's a good one. Now I have played the multiplayer mode on a different account, so don't mind the playtime. The multiplayer is really cool, thank's to Frostbite. Almost everything on the battlefield (pun intented) is destructible, which makes no cover 100% certain. The vehicles also bring depth to the multiplayer mode, since you can, for example ride around in a Jeep or fly a chopper. The multiplayer mode is more fun with your friend(s) (surprise), and you can make a 'squad' just for you and your friends. When you're in a squad with your friends, you can spectate them when dead, and you can also spawn next to them when you're ready, so that you don't have to run all the way back from a control point for example. The campaign mode, however, is the thing that interested me so much that I had to buy it for this account. The campaign's story isn't the most cliche one, but it isn't the most interesting one either. But that isn't even the reason why I wanted to get the game. The campaign simply gets you into a certain mood and additude when you play it. That's why I recommend you to play the campaign mode in dark, so that you can really get into it. My favorite part from the campaign so far is a mission, where you have to snipe, in a rain forest, in a thunderstorm/heavy rain, while in the dark. Playing that mission felt like heaven. So much fun. The price tag isn't too bad either, since it's a fairly old game. The PC multiplayer isn't dead either, so you won't have to worry about that. 8,5/10
